Extract from Inspector Hamilton's report on the Red Earth Indian Day School visited February 13, 1942.

The school building is of log construction and very old. The walls have rotted around the bottom, and the floor is heaved in the centre and in bad condition. If it is not possible to provide a new building, provision should be made for repairing the one now in use. However, this building is very old; the door and windows fit badly, and the floor is very cold. The building does not justify any great expense being incurred in the way of repairs. If possible, consideration should be given to the building of a new log school.
Ottawa,
March 13, 1942.

EXD.

Dear Sir:

The following is an extract from Inspector Hamilton's report regarding his visit to the Red Earth Indian Day School on February 13 last:

"The school building is of log construction and very old. The walls have rotted around the bottom, and the floor is heaved in the centre and in bad condition. If it is not possible to provide a new building, provision should be made for repairing the one now in use. However, this building is very old, the door and windows fit badly, and the floor is very cold. The building does not justify any great expense being incurred in the way of repairs. If possible, consideration should be given to the building of a new log school."

No funds will be available in the appropriation for the fiscal year 1942-43 for the erection of new buildings. However, we might be able to secure some money for repairs. On the occasion of your next visit to Red Earth you should decide what repairs are required and submit an estimate of the cost for our consideration.

Yours truly,

R.A. Rosey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. S. Lovell,
Indian Agent,
The Pas, Man.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6246, file 539-5, part 2)
Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter 128-8-5, dated the 13th March, in connection with repairs for Red Earth School. The following material will be required to make the necessary repairs that Mr. Hamilton had in mind.

50 ft. lx6
50 ft. lx4
18 pieces of 2x8-10
200 feet shiplap.
10 pieces 2x4-10
10 bags cement.
500 feet spruce flooring.

We shall also require a few logs, which can be purchased from the Indians. These will be used for new bottom logs and floor joists.

I estimate the material will cost about $50.00 and the labour $100.00 or a total of $150.00. I will be glad if you will give me authority to spend that amount to make the repairs.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
May 27, 1942.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 21st instant, you may expend an amount of $150.00 in making the necessary repairs to the Red Earth Indian Day School. It is noted from your letter that the amount forwarded will cover the cost of both material and labour.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. S. Lovell,
Indian Agent,
The Pas, Man.

Prince Albert, Saskatchewan.

June 14th, 1946.

R.A. Hoey, Esq.

Dear Sir:

With regard to (2) it is detrimental to the health of the Indian children to allow them to study in buildings in which the wind blows through the walls, and the only warm spot is immediately round the stove. We realize that building material is hard to obtain, but a large number of schools are being built in this Province. The Indians notice this, and say that if schools can be built for the white children, why should they not be built for the Indian children.

Yours Faithfully,

Bishop of Saskatchewan.
Prince Albert Saskatchewan.
June 14th, 1946.

H.A. Hoey, Esq.

Dear Sir:

At a meeting of the Synod of The Diocese of Saskatchewan held on June 13th, 1946, the following resolution was passed: "That a letter be addressed to the Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, asking (1) that the question of the Salaries of the Teachers of Indian Day Schools be reviewed, and that these Teachers be classed as Civil Servants, and have the advantage of the Government Pension Scheme. (2) That old log school buildings, which are cold and draughty in winter, such as exist at Red Earth and Shoal Lake in the Pas Agency, and at Stanley in the Carlton agency, be replaced by well-built lumber class rooms. (3) That new Day Schools be established on those Reserves which have no school at present, and when there are a sufficient number of children to warrant a school. One such Reserve is that of Loon Lake, Saskatchewan."

Hoping that these request will receive the earnest consideration of the Department, I Remain,

yours faithfully,

Bishop of Saskatchewan.

Shoal Lake, Sask., and Red Earth, Sask., schools, both should be shipped direct to Carrot River, Sask., for onward transportation to Shoal Lake Reserve and Red Earth Reserve. Extract from letter from Mr. Ostrander dated June 21st, 1948. Original on file 107-9-1.

I examined the classroom and teacherage at the Red Earth Reserve. The classroom is an old log building and certainly no credit to the Department. The teacherage is very small, difficult to heat, and would not attract any teacher. School attendance is poor, partly because the school is situated at a point which is surrounded by water a great part of the year, and many of the children cannot reach the school for long periods because of the water, and partly because the Indians are trappers and do not seem to be much interested in education.

I did not visit the Shoal Lake Day School as I was informed that it was closed, but Mr. J.R. Bell, in charge of the Sipanok Rat Project, who resides at Red Earth, informed me that conditions at Shoal Lake are even worse than at Red Earth.

Both of these points are so situated that the erection of classrooms and teaching quarters at the two places is out of the question at the present time because of the cost.

I am sending a copy of this letter to Mr. Indian Superintendent Law and am attaching thereto copies of the standard bill of materials for this school. The schoolhouse at Rossville is really a disgrace to the Department. Dr. Strath told me he had over 90 children at this school on the day we arrived, and where they could be packed appeared to me a mystery, notwithstanding his arrangement of biscuit boxes around the stove, and in any available vacancy. The fact is the school house is altogether inadequate in size for so important a point, and as to facilities for proper ventilation there are none. The chimney is both too small in its lateral dimensions, and too low for a proper draught, and into this enters the smallest sized stove pipe. There should be a large chimney with good fire place and built sufficiently high to ensure a draught, which, with a good stove, would give the requisite ventilation in the winter; and the school house doubled in size.

I have the honour to forward the School returns of the Rossville Day School, Norway House, for June quarter last.

It will be noticed from this office receipt stamp that these returns have been delayed here over twenty days, a fact which I beg to explain as follows: The returns were brought to the office by the teacher himself, Mr. Joseph H. Lowes; during a conversation with whom the following facts were elicited: that, contrary to the impression prevailing in the office to the effect that the Rossville Day School and the Norway House Boarding School were some seven miles apart, they are, as a matter of fact, quite close to each other; so much so that the teaching of Boarders and Day Scholars alike is done in the Day School by the Day School teacher.

The consequence is that the names of the Boarders appear on both the Day School and Boarding School returns which the Department may discover by comparing the returns for the March quarter. If this has not been noticed already, it would, I suppose, mean that whilst the Day School was paid on its average, the tuition grant was at the same time paid the Boarding School which, I assume, would have been an overpayment.

After being provided with this information from a person aware of the facts, I thought it better to keep back the returns.

The Deputy Superintendent General:

The teacher of the Rossville Mission school at Norway House reports that this school was closed and on the 8th November by order of the Agent Dr Campbell the building being turned into a temporary hospital on account of an epidemic of diphtheria, scarlet fever measles and mumps. I notice that Mr Laird makes a marginal note to this effect: "The school was only open 17½ days but there was an outbreak of scarlet fever which probably accounts for this". I think we should have Dr Bryce's opinion as to the turning of the schoolhouse into a hospital for such contagious diseases as scarlet fever and diphtheria. The boarders at the Norway House school receive tuition in this building which is close to the boarding school.

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 7th instant in which you recommend an increase in salary from $300.00 to $500.00 for Mr. Thomas Bolster, teacher of the Methodist day school at Norway House.

Of course as you are aware the Department is not responsible for Mr. Bolster's salary as teacher in the Boarding School, but should he be successful in obtaining a much better attendance at the day school the Department would then be prepared to consider your request. Dear Mr. Ferrier:

On October 2nd we received a telegram from the Principal of our Industrial School at Norway House, stating that Mrs. Hill, the day school teacher on the reserve, had resigned and asking us to secure someone for the school—to go up on the last boat, which they thought was leaving on Monday the 6th from Selkirk. I immediately wired Mr. Gordon, the Indian Agent, asking him for official confirmation of the vacancy and whether or not he was depending upon us to fill it. His reply came Saturday afternoon, stating that the school was vacant, that they were depending upon us, and that the last boat did not leave Selkirk until Wednesday the 6th.

We tried by telegram to locate a couple of teachers in Manitoba who had made application for a position of this sort. Unfortunately, we did not succeed in securing their consent and on Monday morning it was necessary to find someone who would be willing to step into the vacancy—either we had to send a teacher up on that boat or wait for six weeks until someone could go in over the ice. Under the circumstances, I decided that I would send Osborne Earle. He is about twenty years of age and is a son of Mrs. Shoup, wife of the Principal of the Norway House Boarding School. I have known Osborne for a good many years, as he was born in China and we lived at one time in the same station. There is no doubt about his ability, nor did we have any difficulty in persuading him to go. He has his lower school complete, but lacks the languages in his upper school subjects. I felt that this would not be a serious handicap, as it is scarcely likely that he will have any students beyond the fifth or sixth grade in the day school at Norway House. Besides, I knew in sending him up there he would be sure of a home in which to live and certain of a reasonable amount of supervision from his mother and step-father. He has had no previous experience in teaching school, but he has had experience as a Sunday School teacher and as a leader of junior Tuxis groups.

I have written Mr. Gordon a full explanation of the reasons why Osborne Earle was appointed and asked him to forward to you his sanction of the appointment. I shall be pleased to hear from you at your convenience as to what salary the Department will allow him. I may say that in sending him off we provided him with
ticket, berth and $100.00.

No word whatever has yet come through as to the reasons for Mrs. Hill's sudden resignation, but when we do get particulars as to exactly what happened, I shall be glad to forward them to you.

Dr. Cochrane and I are expecting to be in Ottawa on the 17th November, and I am looking forward with keen anticipation to meeting you personally.

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]

Sir:

I have the honor to enclose herewith the Quarterly Return for the Rossville Day School, for the quarter ended March 31st, 1931.

The teacher of this school, Mr. Osborn Earl, left Norway House April 12th without giving any notice of his intention. He had taken the Easter holiday week, so that his work was not carried over into this quarter.

On learning that the teacher was gone, and did not intend to return, I consulted with Rev. R.T. Chapin, the United Church Missionary at Norway House, and we engaged the services of David Nanowin as teacher until we could communicate with the Department and the Board of the United Church. We made no arrangements as to salary. David was glad to get the work, as he had come to Norway House from Poplar River several weeks earlier, with the hope that he might secure work of some kind here, and had been idle the greater part of the time, and was on the point of returning to his home at Poplar River.

David Nanowin graduated from the Norway House Indian Residential School in 1923, at the age of nineteen years, and had reached Grade ten in the classroom. He has acted as assistant to Rev. Mr. Caldwell at Poplar River at times, and also Mr. Scheuteze, at Little Grand Rapids. I am keeping in close touch with the school work, and think it will be quite satisfactory. At any rate, it was the best we could do under the circumstances, as the last winter mail had gone, and we have no wireless now, and consequently no means of communication until June.

Trusting the Department will approve our action, and will pay David for his work.

Your obedient servant

Wm. Gordon
Indian Agent.

Dear Mr. Sutherland:

Re: Indian Day School, Norway House

We are in receipt of the resignation of Miss Verna Blackford, who for several years has been the very efficient teacher of the Indian Day School at Norway House, as she is expecting to be married in September.

During my recent visit to Norway House I discussed with Mr. P. J. Lazenby, the Indian Agent, the question of the amalgamation of the teaching service. My profound conviction, after having been on the ground five times, is that both the Department and the Church made a serious mistake when the building which is now used as a day school was moved off the residential school site and the teaching services entirely separated. I recommend - and in this recommendation Mr. Lazenby concurs - that the position of teacher of the day school at Norway House be abolished; that the salary now being paid to the day school teacher be added as a special to the income of the residential school; and that the two teachers now employed in the residential school teach the few pupils who are in the day school.

At the present time - until we have tried this plan out for a year - it would be inadvisable to move the day school building back to the residential school site. It is about 100 yards away on the Reserve and the building could very well be used for teaching the junior grades.

The advantages of the plan are as follows:

1st.- A unification of the education being received by the children on the Norway House Reserve.- At the present time those who are in the residential school are getting a very much better training - even in the class-room - than the day school pupils get.

2nd.- The residential school could take the responsibility for giving the day school students the same hot dinner at noon that the boys and girls in residence receive, and the Nurse could assume responsibility for giving them their rations of Cod Liver Oil and other medicines which are recommended.
3rd.- The day school pupils could be given some of the same training in sewing, handicrafts, &c., which the pupils in residence receive.

4th.- It would place the whole educational process as applied to the Reserve directly under the supervision of the Principal of the residential school. At the present time there is no place for the day school teacher to live except in the residence, and she enjoys all the privileges of life in the residential school which are enjoyed by the other staff members, without any of the after-hour duties which are inevitable in the carrying on of such an institution. The result has naturally been a certain amount of lack of harmony.

5th.- The extra grant which would be available for the residential school could be used to provide a really competent instructor in manual training for the boys.

I sincerely trust that this proposal will meet with the approval of the Department. Dr. McGill is aware that the matter has been under discussion for some time, as we talked it over informally with him during his visit to Norway House last year.

Yours very sincerely,

Sir,

I beg to report that on the 27th October, I inspected the Rossville Indian Day School, which is conducted in conjunction with the Junior Classes of the Norway House Residential School.

On the roll of this school, there are 58 pupils, 47 of these being from the residential school, and 11 belonging to the day school. The residential school pupils only attend for half days; 21 attending in the mornings, and 26 in the afternoons. At the time of my visit, which was in the afternoon, all 26 pupils from the residential school were present, and six of the 11 day school pupils were present. Four of the day school pupils were away with their parents to their winter camps, and one was absent through sickness.

All of the residential school pupils are in grade 1. Of the day school pupils, 8 are in grade 1, 1 in grade 2, 1 in grade 4, and 1 in grade 5.

The work of the pupils generally is good. Their book work; writing, drawing etc. is commendable, but there is room for much improvement in their reading still. The discipline is very good, and both teacher and pupils show much interest in the school work.

The school building was clean and tidy. The new stove recently furnished for this school was in operation, and the building was warm and comfortable. Two new panes of glass were needed in the windows, and these have been installed. The teacher complained that as there was no lock on the outside door of this school, outsiders were frequently going in, and interfering with things. I therefore purchased a hasp and padlock, and had them put on the door.

I would recommend that a woven wire fence be erected around this school and its small grounds next summer, with two gates; one large one and one small one. This would keep horses and cattle away from the building, and greatly improve the appearance of the place. As it is now, the fire wood gets scattered about, and in all probability it is the animals that break the windows.

Your obedient Servant,

P.G. Lazenby,
Indian Agent.

Sir,

I beg to report that on the 23rd instant I inspected the Rossville United Church Indian Day School, which is conducted in conjunction with the junior class-room of the Norway House Residential School.

There were 50 Residential School pupils, and 14 Day School pupils on the roll; the residential school pupils attending class room on the half day system. Of the 50 residential school pupils, there were 21 present, and of the day school pupils there were 9 present, at the time of my visit. The register was marked up to date.

All the pupils were clean and tidy, and were well clothed.

The school building inside was kept clean and orderly.

The discipline was good. Reading aloud was only fair, the pupils not speaking out at all well, but the book work was better, being well done.

With reference to this school being conducted in conjunction with the junior section of the residential school, I beg to call attention to the final paragraph of Departmental letter No; 123-8-1 of the 31st July 1935.

Reference to the quarterly reports for the Rossville Day School reveals that the average attendance has declined greatly since the amalgamation of this school with the residential school. Before the amalgamation, the average attendance had stood at approximately 12 to 14, but during the past year, it has dropped to an average of 5. I talked this matter over with the Principal of the residential school, and the only conclusion I can come to, is that the 'Day School' aspect has been practically lost sight of; interest being centered chiefly in the 'Residential School' aspect. Prior to the amalgamation of the two schools, the teacher of the Rossville Day School gave her entire time to that school, and whenever any of the pupils were absent she was at pains to discover the reason for the absence, and get after the parents of the pupils and insist on their being sent to school, but at present, it would seem that the absence of a few of the day school pupils among the larger number of residential school pupils is not noticed, or if it is noticed, nothing is done about it. The "experiment" has not proven to be the success hoped for.

In these circumstances, unless the Department wishes -

Sir,

On receipt of Mr R.A.Hey's letter No; 123-8-1 of the 15th July, I again discussed with the Principal of the Norway House Residential School, the best policy to pursue in the future, for the best interests of the Rossville Indian Day School, which for the past two years, has been conducted in conjunction with the Residential School.

On going thoroughly into the matter, it was found that to re-establish this school on its former basis, as a separate entity, a number of new desks, some blackboard, and a stove would have to be furnished, in order that the junior class room of the residential school, (which was always conducted in a separate building), might be started again; and the residential school would have to get a new junior class room teacher, when there was only a very short time left before school commenced after the vacation.

If the Rossville school is carried on for another year, in conjunction with the junior class room of the residential school, the Principal has agreed to make the following arrangements:- Give the teacher only one after 4 p.m. duty; Saturdays free; two only, evening duties; and a smaller Residential school junior class. He has also offered to give every assistance himself, to see that the Rossville Day School progresses.

In view of the foregoing, and with more time and attention given by both teacher and Principal, to the interests of the Rossville Day school, I see no reason why the day school should not make headway, and I therefore recommend that these schools be carried on as heretofore with the above mentioned changes in policy adopted, and should be glad if you would advise me if this has approval.

DÉCLARATION À REMPLIR PAR LES CHEFS DE FAMILLE

Cette déclaration doit être remplie, en deux exemplaires, par les titulaires d’un emploi continu, susceptibles d’être considérés comme chefs de famille, et dont la rétribution est inférieure à $108 par mois, et par toutes les femmes mariées au service de cette administration. Elle doit être remise au ministère qui en garde un exemplaire et envoie l’autre au délégué en chef du Trésor, pour être transmise au Bureau de paye.

"Chef de famille" signifie une personne mariée, homme ou femme, une personne (homme ou femme) célibataire ou divorcée, ou veuve, qui entretient un établissement domestique d’un seul tenant, et qui y fait vivre réellement une personne entièrement à sa charge, lui étant pas liée par le lien du sang ou mariage ou de l’adoption.

(i) "Établissement domestique d’un seul tenant" signifie un logis, un appartement ou autre semblable lieu de résidence contenant au moins une chambre à coucher, et dans lequel, en règle générale, l’employé couche et où ses repas sont préparés et servis.

(ii) Une personne unie à l’employé par les liens du mariage signifie son époux ou épouse, les père, mère, oncles, tantes, neveux, nièces, grands-parents et arrière-grands-parents du conjoint de l’employé, les beaux-fils, belles-filles, beaux-frères et belles-sœurs de l’employé.

(iii) Une personne unie à l’employé par les liens du sang signifie ses parents, parents nourriciers, grands-parents, arrière-grands-parents, enfants, petits-enfants, arrière-petits-enfants, frères ou sœurs, oncles ou tantes, neveux ou nièces.

(iv) L’expression "unie à l’employé par les liens de l’adoption" comprend l’adoption de fait aussi bien que l’adoption légale.

Sir,

There is a matter to which I wish to refer;

In connection with the day-schools on the different reserves on my Agency, I find it impossible to get the Indians to take enough interest in these schools to furnish the wood required to keep the buildings warm during the winter. It frequently happens that the teacher is compelled to close the school for want of wood to heat the building. Spending a day on each reserve twice in the year, you can understand that the Agent has very little chance to get after them. Now I have a proposition to make and I am convinced that it will work so well that it will rarely have to be used after the one example is made of those who fail to do their share. I want to be allowed at treaty time to impose a fine of $1.00 on each able bodied head of a family who has not during the year put in a cord of wood to the school. In anticipation of this, during my winter visit to the reserves, I informed them all that I wanted every man to put in his wood, get the teacher to measure it and give him a note stating that he had supplied his wood, and this certificate he is to present at treaty time. I would collect the fine from each delinquent in the presence of the chief, and when finished would hand the amount collected, to the teacher or missionary in charge, taking his receipt for it and would arrange with him to use the money in hiring the Indians to supply wood, and have him take receipts from each Indian for the amount paid him for wood. In this way everything would be kept straight, and as I have said, after the first year I am confident it will not be ne
be necessary. The chiefs and head-men of the various reserves are altogether in favour of adopting this method, as they claim that the work of supplying the wood falls upon a few who are more reasonable than the others.

If some such method is not adopted, I can see no other way than for the Department, to provide for wood in the estimates, and I think that would be wholly bad.

I have gone into the matter very fully, for two winters now on each of the reserves, explaining to the Indian how the white man is compelled by law to build his own school, furnish it supply fuel, pay the teacher, and everything, while the Indian has all these done for him, only being asked to supply the wood, and send his children; but it is pretty much lost upon an Indian. There is nothing in him to appeal to, and the only way is to make him feel it, through his pocket. I would be very grateful for an early reply.

I have the honour to be,

Sir;

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Ottawa, February 23, 1948.

Dear Miss Fleming:

I have to advise you, that after considerable effort on the part of our Department, the Treasury Board has recommended the permanent appointment of certain Indian Day School teachers.

You are included among those who are now eligible for appointment to a permanent position for the purpose of superannuation. It will, of course, be necessary to present the required evidence of age and health to the Chief of the Superannuation and Retirement Fund Branch of the Department of Finance before you may become a contributor under the Civil Service Superannuation Act.

You will find attached the following documents:

(a) Two copies of Physical Examination Record (N. H. & W. Form 502).
(b) One copy of "Civil Service Superannuation Act" (Form PA 74).
(c) Three copies of Civil Service Superannuation Act Election Form (Fin No. 64).
(d) One copy of Memorandum re War Service (5/1947).
(e) One copy of Memorandum re Pensionable Employment (6/1947).

Physical Examination:

We will require completion of the attached physical examination record (N. H. & W. Form 502). It is suggested that you have this form completed by either your own personal doctor or by a doctor of the Indian Health Services of the Department of National Health and Welfare. This form, when completed, should then
Civil Service Health Division,
Department of National Health and Welfare,
Ottawa, Canada.

Please note that any expense attendant upon this examination will be borne by you.

Election to Contribute for Past Service:

When a Civil Servant has served in a temporary capacity, prior to being a contributor to the Civil Service Superannuation Act, he may, within twelve months of the date of his permanent appointment, elect to contribute an amount equal to five, five and one half or six percent of the total salary received by him during such period of service with simple interest thereon at the rate of four percent per annum. By reference to section II para 2 of the Civil Service Superannuation Act pamphlet (FA 74) attached, you can determine the rate of contribution in your instance.

Our records show that you have been an Indian Day School Teacher for a period of approximately three years. Therefore, it will be necessary for you to pay contributions, if you so elect, to the fund in either one lump sum or in installments. You will find a table of installments on page 2 of the election form (Fin No. 64).

If you desire to have this temporary service count for Superannuation purposes, kindly complete the enclosed forms (Fin No. 64) and return them in duplicate to this office. I may point out that by Section 7 A (1) of the act, only service which is fully paid for shall be counted.

War Service:

A memorandum is attached for the information of contributors who may be eligible to count their War Service for purposes of the Civil Service Superannuation Act.
Pensionable Employment:

If you have had service with the Dominion Government prior to your present appointment, you should immediately furnish this office with full particulars regarding the nature of such service and the salary received.

If you have had other pensionable employment (e.g., as a provincial teacher) you will find details as to conditions, procedure, etc., outlined in the memorandum attached, dealing with "Pensionable Employment" (6/1947).

Your attention is directed to para 2 under "Conditions" in this memorandum in which you will note that your contribution "for such employment shall be twice the amount that he would have contributed etc.,".

Under para 2 of "Exceptions", you are not entitled to count provincial service for Dominion Superannuation services, when you are already receiving or have received a provincial superannuation benefit.

Deductions:

I may add that from December 27, 1947, a percent (as determined by the Civil Service Superannuation Act Form 74 A) will be deducted from your salary on account of the superannuation fund. Whether or not you decide to contribute for past service, I would appreciate being informed at the earliest possible date of your decision.

I would finally remind you that you are given twelve months to make the election described above and that this offer expires on December 27, 1948. Therefore, it is most important that you inform the Department of your decision whether to allow for past service or not.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Miss Laura M. Fleming,
Norway House Indian Day School,
Norway House, Manitoba.

Dear Sir:

There are certain aspects of Indian education in this area which I thought it worthwhile to bring to your attention. First there is the matter of the location of Day Schools associated with the United Church. The present arrangement of three schools in a block at Rossville results in severe hardship to a significant number of pupils to the point where those most seriously affected find it very difficult to secure education at all or at least have their schooling seriously delayed. I refer here to those families living on the Jack River. The distance between Rossville and the nearest school down the river is about five miles. The real problem, however, is not so much the distance involved as the fact that these children have to cross a windswept bay of one mile just before reaching school. The result is that children cannot start to school until they are about 8 or 10 and even then lose many days when the weather is not good and at freeze-up and break-up. Besides this at present 10 or 11 of our children are forced to attend the Catholic School. Let me assure you, however, that this situation calls for attention aside altogether from the war of churches. I know from personal experience what the situation is because neither my son nor the daughter of the H.B.C. manager here would be receiving education were it not for the courtesy of
your department in allowing them to attend your schools as it is impossible for them to cross the same bay (in a different direction) to attend the Provincial school.

I have carefully investigated the population of the area concerned and find that there are at least 43 children who would be benefited by the erection of the proposed school. This is aside from one or two Catholic families. There are about 35 pre-school age children. At the present time there are at least two families who have gone off trapping, fishing etc., taking their children for the simple reason that they could not attend school. This area has a fairly stable population and many of the people are genuinely anxious to further their children's education. In fact, if this school could be erected I doubt if any of the children would be taken to winter camp. From personal contacts I know that there is a unanimous desire for this school.

One reason I have written you at this time is that I have heard that it has been proposed to build a four-room school at Rossville. If this is for use as a Residential school that is an excellent idea; but if it is intended to serve as a day-school it will not meet the education requirements of this district. We had the same problem in connection with the provincial schools last summer when a central two-room school was discarded in favour of two one-room schools separately located. It might well be that all of the higher grades could be taught at Rossville as it would not be so hard for the older children to cross the above mentioned Bay, but certainly for the beginners there should be a school which can be easily reached. If you have a large scale map of this area which you could send me I would be only too glad to indicate location of
such a school. I think the school would be best located about a mile from the mouth of the Jack River.

I have spoken to Mr. Hughes, the local agent, and although he had not personally investigated the matter, he was inclined to agree with me. At any rate if it is true that a four-room block is to be erected it should be perfectly clear that there is a need for this school as well and that such a block can never meet the educational needs of the children to which I have referred.

It is hard for one up here to get a clear picture of the future policy of your Department relative to the Residential school and I am writing what immediately follows to try and emphasize one point i.e. that the use which is to be made of the four room block should be clearly determined as for Residential purposes or at least partly so. I realize that this is a thorny question but should like also to offer my advice in this connection. By nature and on the basis of my previous knowledge of the factors involved I was severely critical of the Residential idea but contact with actual conditions up here has altered my opinion. We still have reserves inland where it is impossible to operate winter schools owing to housing conditions. Furthermore there are the persistent problems of orphans and families with one or both parents out at the Sanitorium. Besides which there are a significant number of homes in which the moral atmosphere is so bad that removal from the home is the only possible way of giving the children a chance and the Residential school seems to me the most practical means of doing this. For example there is a home here in which the father is little more than a pimp and a bootlegger, the mother a prostitute, both of whom have been forbidden to ever set foot in Winnipeg again. Children in such a home have not a hope in the
world of ever becoming useful citizens. Fortunately not many homes are as bad as this one but there are enough of a similar nature to warrant some sort of organized action. I might add that a boy from the above mentioned home was forcibly sent out to school i.e., regardless of his parent's consent as a juvenile delinquent and when he came home on holiday was allowed to remain in this debilitating moral atmosphere as a result of the Agent's prejudice against the Residential school. I am certain that had this situation existed in any white community some action would have been taken. As I have suggested the Residential School offers the only practical method I have yet seen of handling these cases.

I must admit that I have little enthusiasm for the policy of dragooning up a quota of pupils and just wish that these institutions could be operated as social agencies without this pupilage payment arrangement. Furthermore, concerning the four room block I wonder if your Department has ever considered the possibility of a Residential High School at this point. At the present time there is not a single high school in this whole area east of The Pas. In this connection I fail to see why it should not be possible for Dominion and Provincial governments to work together to set up a high school. There are several non-treaty children taking high school outside at great expense to their parents. As for the Treaty children very few of them reach grade 9 and if they do there is not much to encourage them as Correspondents and practically no fellow students are the order of the day. In fact one of the blackest marks against the Day School system is that there just are not any of their graduates, in this district at any rate, who have ever gone beyond Grade 9. Personally, this Day Residential argument appears one of the most futile bits of wasted
human endeavour that I have ever seen. The truth of the matter is that to meet the educational need of the Indian people we need both methods. I do hope that the possibility of a joint Residential High School will be seriously entertained as such an Institution would provide an objective for the superior students all across the north. In view of the better day school facilities which are being provided for the inland reserves it would appear that the necessity and value of such an institution will increase as the years go by.

The drift of the above is that the Residential school of the future should be of a two-fold nature viz., social redemption and specialization. In addition to High School there might well be courses in mechanics or carpentry training. The economic possibilities of this area seem to be decreasing if changing at all. With a growing population one of the greatest needs is that a minority at least of the people should be qualified to take on some of the mechanical work which is done up here. Every year dozens of carpenters etc. come up here to do work much of which could be done by Indians if they were properly trained. I realize that such work is not congenial to the temperament of many of the Indians but the number of "Old Faithfuls" around the Agency and Hospital indicate that the wanderlust of many of them is fading. This touches on one of the central weaknesses of Indian education viz. that there is a very tenuous relation between the present educational process and the economic life of the people. This is not to suggest that the only purpose of education is to line one's pocket but one has only to have scant observation of ordinary society to realize the extent to which enthusiasm for education among "civilized" people is related to economic utility. The enlarging of spiritual outlook should be accompanied by increased economic effectiveness. At present such enthusiasm for education as the Indian has
is largely a matter of infinite faith and idealism. I realize that this will long be a grave problem but do hope that it will be possible as the years go by to infuse the present literary education with more habits and skills which will specifically improve the economic competence of the Indian in his actual environment. In connection with this I would be pleased to know whether there is or are any Summer Schools for Indian teachers, where such aspects of the work could be developed and discussed.

Finally I hope that the loads of advice I have distributed in this letter have not made it appear that I have been endeavouring to inform you as to the nature of your vocation! I have merely written as I have on the presumption that observations on the field will be welcome. Before closing may I commend the energy which your Department has displayed in construction of schools in this Agency. In this commendation I include Mr. Goodman who despite the criticism voiced above was always held in high esteem and whose recent death was very keenly felt.

I realize that you must have a multitude of duties but if you could reply to this letter in the proximate future I would greatly appreciate your course.

Sincerely yours,

Rev. G.C. Johnson,
United Church Missionary,
Norway House, Man.

Dear Doctor Dorey:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of February 25, 1949, concerning the Norway House Residential School.

As you are no doubt aware, our Education officials have been giving a great deal of consideration to the educational needs of the Indians of the Norway House Agency. An inspection trip of the area made two years ago revealed that the day schools were in a very poor state of repair. Since then, we have completed two modern and well constructed day schools for children of your denomination at Island Lake and at Cross Lake. At the present time, we have two complete sets of materials for other day schools en route by tractor train to God's Lake Narrows and to Oxford House. Funds have been provided in our 1949-50 Estimates for the construction of these schools next summer.

With regard to the rebuilding of the Norway House Residential School, I may say that the necessary ground survey for this project was completed last summer by two surveyors who were employed by the Department of Public Works in connection with the proposed building of a hospital by the Indian Health Services Branch. Our Lands and Development Services Branch has been asked to prepare a set of drawings for the rebuilding of this school but, unfortunately, we have not been able to advise them specifically as to the size of the building.
which should be erected. Our inspectors reported that previously a considerable number of children from the immediate vicinity of Norway House attended the residential school when they could well have been attending day schools. It has been suggested that a day school be built across the Bay to provide educational facilities for the children there. It is claimed that this area has a stable population and that if a day school were erected there, few, if any, of the children would be taken to winter camp.

We appreciate the fact that inland from Norway House there are a number of reserves on which it is very difficult to successfully operate day schools, due to the conditions under which the Indians live. There is also the persistent problem of orphans and families with one or both parents in hospital for treatment for tuberculosis.

The pupilage at the former Norway House Residential School was 105. The problem now is to decide definitely the pupilage of the proposed new school. We had hoped to arrive at a definite answer following the recent visit of one of our officials, but, unfortunately, weather conditions prevented his landing at certain reserves on which there were Indians belonging to the United Church of Canada. You will appreciate the fact that the building of residential schools is today a very costly undertaking. Therefore, we must be careful in building a school which will suffice for our needs but will not be too large for the Indian population it is intended to serve. Naturally, we wish the children for whom day school facilities are provided to attend such schools and we do not wish them placed in a residential school in order to fill it. I would, therefore, like to hear from you as to the views of your local missionaries, and to receive statements from them as to the number of children of your Church in their various missions who actually require residential school care and education. We could then have this information reviewed by our officials.
I have noted your comments with regard to the Teslin Residential School. The need of a residential school at this point was brought to the attention of the department some ten years ago and assurances were subsequently given that construction would proceed once materials and labour became readily available. The welfare situation has been aggravated by conditions resulting from the presence of soldiers of the United States army and workers who were employed in the building of the Alaska Highway. Due to the unusually large number of welfare cases in the Teslin area, which require institutional care, the department feels that a residential school is an urgent necessity.

I should like to assure you, however, that the residential school requirements of the United Church of Canada at Norway House are being carefully borne in mind, provision having been made in the 1949-50 Estimates for the construction of the first unit of the new school, namely the classroom block.

Yours sincerely,

Jas. A. MacKinnon.

On Indian Schools

Sir: Your report of the discussion on Indian education at our recent Manitoba United Church conference is quite misleading. From this article one would gather that the Indian people and their education are interested only in footballs. On behalf of the United church I wish to deny this implication.

The first issue dealt with was that of residential versus day schools. We are more than happy to see the great extension of day school facilities in which the government is at present engaged. At the same time we are aware of the needs of special areas and mindful of the special capacities of residential schools we protest the policy of closing all residential schools. What the Indians need is both day and residential schools.

I also protest strongly the manner in which I was quoted out of context. Firmly opposed as I am to Rome, I am more than happy to see that principle of equality that I was suggesting to the conference was that the first principle involved in the surrender of the churches' responsibilities in Indian education should be that of equality. At the present time seven Protestant residential schools have been closed for various reasons said, to the best of my knowledge not on Catholic grounds.

It is the policy of Catholic expansion at the same time that we are being asked to withdraw that same fort and will continue to draw forth my protest.

Rev. G. O. Johnson
Norway House, Man.

Dear Colonel Gibson:

Re Norway House Residential School

Your predecessor, Hon. James A. MacKinnon, wrote me on March 9, 1949, to ask our views on certain matters related to the rebuilding of the School.

I must apologize for the considerable delay in answering the letter. I should say that getting replies back from these Northern Reserves is the reason for it.

I am writing to say that after consultation with our missionaries and others in the Manitoba Conference, it is our judgment -

(1) That the Residential School at Norway House is required to meet the needs of the children on the Northern Manitoba Reserves whose parents are members and adherents of our Church.

(2) That this rebuilding should be undertaken immediately as there is a serious loss of education and training because it is not in operation.

(3) That it should provide accommodation for some 125 children. The missionaries believe that, given the co-operation of Department Officials in enforcing attendance, the School will be filled to full capacity.

I shall be glad to have an opportunity of discussing this matter with you at your convenience.

Yours sincerely,

Norway House Residential School

In reply to your letter under file No. 581-1 dated September 2, 1949, Mr. Davis, Regional Supervisor, presently away on holidays, left the following information and asked that I reply to your letter under file previously quoted.

Mr. Davis states that while he is not in favour of residential schools his opinion is that in the north, where the Indians are trapping and hunting, it is most essential that we should have a school at this point.

I feel that when drawing plans for a school of this type it would be less expensive to build the school along the same plans as an Army Camp - one storey buildings and the buildings separate. In the event of fire the children could very easily leave the buildings and we would possibly only lose one or two buildings at the most. Another feature would be that all buildings could be heated by a central heating station.

If a building of this type were erected the majority of the lumber could be manufactured on the spot from our own mill. By doing this we would save considerable expense and, in addition, furnish employment for the Indians concerned.

If the Department intends to build next year we should have plenty of time in order to secure funds for the taking out and sawing of the logs required for lumber.

Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Within the last year a certain number of Protestant children have been enrolled in Catholic Residential Schools in this area. I have discovered that some of these children were baptised Catholics before being admitted but am fairly certain that this was not the case in every instance. My first question is, Can a child of Protestant faith be admitted to a Roman Catholic school if the child's parents approve his admission? I would also appreciate information concerning the admission of Milton Queskekapow to the Jack River branch of the Catholic Residential school. I have inquired at the local Indian office and they have no record of his admission. I would appreciate your forwarding me a copy of his admission assuming this is available. He was admitted on Oct. 1, 1948.

I would also appreciate an explicit statement concerning Residential School admissions in general. I am under the impression that no child whose environment is normal and who is within reasonable distance of day schools is to be admitted to Residential Schools. I would appreciate your informing me as to what the policy precisely is. Also I would appreciate your assurance that this policy is being applied impartially regardless of religious affiliation. Last year at the time that we were having great difficulty securing admissions of our own children to our own schools several of our children were "stolen" by the Catholic school.

In passing I should like to make the following comment on the objectives of Indian education into this area. One of the greatest needs of Norway House is that up to possibly 50% of the population should be removed. There just are not enough natural resources to go around. My own feeling is that the Residential school is best designed to fit a person technically, emotionally etc. to make the step of leaving his own community.

........2
With population trends what they are here the slightest depression across the country is going to create a gigantic relief situation at Norway House. This is one reason why I am trying to send as many children as possible to Residential school as the day school seems most likely to leave people just where they are. I feel that the government will have to take energetic measures to find an area where some of the population here can be accommodated and also to convince the people that it is for their best welfare that they should move. This would be a long term program and I have mentioned it here to give if possible, justification for my plea that children be admitted to Residential schools from this area. The seriousness of the situation to which I refer is indicated by the large amounts which have been expended locally by the department this year for relief purposes.

When you are replying I would be glad to hear of latest developments relative to the day school on the Jack River and also the new Residential school for Norway House.

Sincerely yours,

(sgd;) Gilbert C. Johnson.

Dear Dr. Dorey:

I have for answer your letter of October 31, and I assure you that I do not know which of our officials, if any, informed Miss Jessup that her services must cease at the end of November. On October 17, 1949, we were advised by the Agency clerk at Norway House that Miss Jessup had advised him that she would be unable to teach beyond December 15. She requested that the Department take steps to obtain a replacement for that date.

Miss Jessup has a First Class Ontario Certificate and has been teaching in Toronto since 1923. Presumably she has been advised that she can not draw superannuation and continue to teach. The crux of this matter would seem to be whether she retired because of age or whether she retired because of sickness. I note from her application form that she was born on October 31, 1896. Therefore, I presume that she retired because of sickness, and I presume that the superannuation officials in Toronto have found out that she is well enough to resume teaching duties elsewhere.

A great deal of the above paragraph is surmise on my part because I do not have any facts other than those presented in the opening paragraph. I hope this helps you in clarifying this situation.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Henry,
Superintendent of Education.

Dear Sir -

I am enclosing herewith certain accounts with the Indian Department and ask if you will kindly see that they are dealt with as promptly as possible.

Re: The 1st and 2nd items on the list I may say that I did not think at the time to take vouchers - but knowing me as you do - also the men named in the two accounts perhaps a word from you will be sufficient.

Then referring to the last item - that of issuing the "Institute Supplies" I may say that in March 1899 Mr. Short (then Indian Agent) asked me if I would issue these supplies at the same time saying that would recommend to the Department that I be paid $15.00 a year for so doing.

By his letter (enclosed) of Jan. 2nd 1900 it appears that he did so. However upon inquiring at the Office in Winnipeg I find he did not do so promptly. I think I should be paid for the full time as his remuneration is no fault of mine.
By the way - What is the present arrangement about raising the supplies. My reason for asking is this - Chas Paul (Councillor) told me that you had said when here treaty time that you were leaving me a letter about it against my return. Well no such letter has turned up and Chief Sinclair as well as the Councillor (as far as I know) seems to be in the dark about it.

Joseph H. Lowe

Sir,

Have received the inclosed correspondence. I have great confidence and respect for Mr. Lowes. Am quite sure he would not prefer a claim without being convinced that it is legitimate. I cannot however find any other reference to the matter in the office than Mr. Short's letter contains and that I inclose. My duty in the case is not clear enough to warrant me in issuing a voucher without authority from yourself. Bear with me therefore for referring it to you for direction.

Mr. Lowes has been appointed to take charge of and issue the supplies for the Destitute for the current year but up till now no mention of pay has been mentioned on either side. It is my conviction that in all such cases where time is taken up and energy consumed and responsibility involved there should be compensation.

Sir:

Relative to the ten school desks asked for by the teacher of the Rossville Indian Day School, I have to request that you will state whether these are of the double or single type. Original on File 123-5-1.

Today, the 21st April, I inspected the junior classroom of the residential school, which is conducted in amalgamation with the Rossville Indian Day School.

The Day School building, and its equipment were in good condition, clean, and well kept. Both Day and Residential School registers were marked up to date. The pupils' book work was generally very good; both writing and figures being well and neatly made; and the arithmetic was generally accurate. With regard to the reading, the chief difficulty is getting the pupils to speak out so that they can be heard. These pupils of course are just young children, and no doubt they will improve in time.

A new stove is needed in this school and I would recommend that one be provided before next winter.

Norway House, Man.,
28th October 1936

Sir:

I beg to report that on the 27th October, I inspected the Rossville Indian Day School, which is conducted in conjunction with the Junior classes of the Norway House Residential school.

The school building was clean and tidy. The new stove recently furnished for this school was in operation, and the building was warm and comfortable. Two new panes of glass were needed in the windows, and these have been installed. The teacher complained that as there was no lock on the outside door of this school, outsiders were frequently going in, and interfering with things. I therefore purchased a hasp and padlock, and had them put on the door.

I would recommend that a woven wire fence be erected around this school and its small grounds next summer, with two gates; one large one and one small one. This would keep horses and cattle away from the building and greatly improve the appearance of the place. As it is now, the fire wood gets scattered about, and in all probability it is the animals that break the windows.

Your obedient servant,

P. G. Lazenby.
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 1st instant enclosing requisition for paint, brushes, fencing etc. for the Rossville Indian Day School.

I am enclosing requisitions for school material for the Rossville Indian Day School. I have visited this school several times. Like most of the Day Schools in this Agency, it is in a dilapidated and rundown condition.

The interior is depressing both for the pupils and the teacher.

New desks are badly needed. The ones in use are ancient, abused and are for the most part, patched up cripples. Also due to the Family Allowance, there are many more pupils than there are desks, although there is room for installation of more desks.

If authority is granted for the purchase of these desks will you please wire me in care of Inspector Hamilton's office, in order that we may obtain the desks before navigation closes on Lake Winnipeg.

E. B. Goodman,

Attention: Mr Bernard F Neary

The enclosed requisitions for School Material are for the 3 Rossville U.C. Day Schools Rundel, Ta-pas-ta-num and Pi-se-qui-nip and are for the academic year 1948-49. I would like especially to draw your attention to the request for 2 school stoves or heating units. E.B. Goodman,
Indian Agent.

Bernard F. Neary

Dear Sir,

I am turning over to you the following drawings, prepared from my surveys at Rossville, Manitoba.

A tracing showing the location of buildings at Rossville, Manitoba, prepared on a scale of 50 feet to the inch.

In connection with the position of sewer and water lines, it should be pointed out that certain of these lines, such as the sewer from the old school site to the septic tank and the sewer from the Agency Office could be located closely by evidence on the ground, but most of the other lines had to be placed on the plan from information supplied largely from memory by members of the Agency staff.

A tracing showing the School Site Parcel "A" and the Engineers' Lot Parcel "B", together with the ties to existing property lines in the area. Please have a Vandyke made of this tracing, as well as two or three blueprints so that I may have a record of the tracing. When you submit this tracing to Ottawa, please inform them that if they wish to make further tracings of this plan, these can be sent to Winnipeg for my signature. In the case of plans for registration in the Land Titles Offices in this Province, the Surveyor is required to furnish two tracings on linen for the Land Titles Office. In the case of Land Surveys in unorganized areas, two tracings must be supplied to the Director of Surveys Office, and of course, in either case, a tracing goes to the party who orders the survey.

Sheet 1 shows the elevations and contours on the school site. A plan showing the locations of the school lot and of the soundings taken on the two sides of the point.

Sheet 2 shows the profiles plotted from the sounding data, as well as a profile of the existing sewer line from the old School that was destroyed by fire several years ago. It will be observed that a plan is also shown, showing the location of these sewers with soundings to rick along a line six feet offset to the south of the existing sewer.

On August 9th, I again checked the water levels in the two concrete manholes along the line and also the level in the concrete manhole near the water's edge, as well as the water levels in the septic tank. The water level in the two concrete manholes along the sewer line was standing at practically the same level in both, and its elevation had risen since my previous measurement on August 7th. The water level

(cont'd)
in the septic tank intake section stood at 102.8, considerably below the water level in the manhole next to the east. I called Mr. Jackson's attention to the fact that the sewer line between this manhole and the septic tank must have some obstruction, and that unless action was soon taken, the manhole would overflow and the sewer would back up further.

I understand the obstruction was located and the broken sewer pipe was repaired after opening it up at the region of the trouble. Further, I was informed that in the septic tank the screen in the dividing wall of the septic tank must have been plugged, thus accounting for the difference of about 1.4 feet in the difference in water level on the two sides of the dividing wall in the septic tank. Moreover, when I examined the septic tank a short piece of 2" x 4" lumber was found sticking upright in the bell of the outlet pipe. This obstruction was removed. I recommended to Mr. Jackson and his assistant that the septic tank should be cleaned out; whether this was done or not, I am not able to say.

The profile shows the approximate sewer elevations from the second most easterly manhole to the septic tank based on the presumption that the grades are straight grades from manhole to manhole and from the first manhole east to the septic tank. The grade line of the sewer was apparently kept up in order to save rock excavation near Station 10. The profile shows that a large part of the sewer has a cover of less than 6 feet. You will note in my records of soundings on the offset line that in several places we encountered frost on August 7th at about 6 feet down, but that we were able to penetrate the frost with the 1/2 inch pointed steel rod. Further, the frost continued to a depth of about 8 feet below the surface. In Winnipeg sewers are given an earth cover of not less than 7.5 feet. In view of the very shallow earth covers over the sewer and the extremely small and intermittent flow from the Principal's Residence, the Engineer's Office and living quarters above the Agency Office, the sewer will be sure to freeze up in all but a very mild winter. Under these circumstances the sewer lines, manholes and septic tank should be protected against frost until such time as the new school is built. Protection could be provided by covering the present sewer line with about two more feet of earth cover, and the manholes and septic tank could be protected by covering them with a foot or more of manure or hay. Since the covering of the sewer with additional earth cover would make a ridge across the Reserve common, perhaps a covering with a foot or more of manure that could be removed in the summertime would be least objectionable, but not a permanent cure.

I also examined the 3" Anthese Foundry Cast Iron sewer outlet into Little Playgreen Lake. I found this waste pipe to be broken in two places, and regret that my plan shows the location of only one break. However, there are two breaks, caused no doubt by shifting ice. This cast iron pipe simply rests on a support or two on the bottom of the lake bed which is very shallow for some distance out from shore, actually only about 3.5 feet deep, about 90 feet from the shore where the pipe enters the water.

(Cont'd)
Even if the outlet pipe is repaired, which repairs should be carried out before freeze up, there is no hope that the pipe line will not be soon broken again. Cast iron cannot stand much shifting and as long as the pipe is exposed, as it is to ice movements, breaks are likely to occur. It will be noted from our soundings that the bay bottom in most places had a mud cover of from 1.5 to 3.0 feet in depth with rock bottom showing without cover in only a few places. In view of these conditions, I believe that a trench could be scraped out along the pipe line to a depth of about 1.5 feet and the pipe line could be extended into slightly deeper water by a shallow cribwork sunk about the outlet to prevent it from silting over. A more flexible outlet pipe line could have been used advantageously in the present location. This waste pipe discharges the fluid from the hospital septic tank as well as from the old septic tank by the Mission lot fence, and for that reason it is advisable to put the line into such repair that it can be expected to function fairly satisfactorily.

I have gone into the investigation of this sewer line from the old school and the outlet to the both sewer lines at the suggestion of Mr. Goodman, when he discussed the situation with me at Rossville, and trust that my report and suggestions may be found helpful.

Further, in the copy of the letter from Mr. R.A. Gibson, Director of Lands and Development Services Branch, Department of Mines and Natural Resources, dated June 28th, 1948, and written to Mr. Robt. Blais, Chief Engineer of your Department, the following paragraph sets out my work:

"It is hoped that the existing buildings may be tied into some determinate point, borings to determine the nature of the soil, depth to rock, elevations of water table and that spot levels over the area may be made, as well as water levels and soundings of Little Playgreen Lake, bordering the Agency and other data relevant to the development of the Agency."

The soundings to be taken were later reduced considerably, and those taken and shown on Sheet No. 1 were taken only over a comparatively narrow set of ranges adjacent to the present water intake and sewer outlet lines.

Please be good enough to have a Vandyke made of my drawings and six white prints run off. Two or three of each of these white prints together with a copy of this letter should be sent to the Indian Agent's Secretary at Rossville, so that work of repairing the sewer outlet pipe and of protecting the old school sewer line against severe winter weather may be completed before freeze up.

One of the other white prints of each of these two sheets would be for my own records.

Please accept my thanks for your generous co-operation in arranging for desk space and use of facilities in the preparation of the Building Location plan drawn by Prof. W.F. Riddell, and in having your office staff make the several tracings. This assistance has been a very great help.

Yours truly,

(sgd) G.H. Herrick D & M.L.S.

MEMORANDUM

Ottawa, October 30, 1948.

Re: Residential School,
Norway House Agency,
Rossville, Manitoba.

In compliance with your marginal notation of June 21st on a memorandum dated June 18th last from the Director of Indian Affairs, we requested the Department of Public Works to have their survey party on the above Agency include in their operations the location of an area on which a proposed Residential School might be located, together with such data as soil conditions, certain soundings off shore in Little Playgreen Lake, location of sewers and existing buildings relative to the school development.

We have now received from Mr. Robert Blais, Chief Engineer of the Department of Public Works, the following plans, of which two copies each are enclosed for the information of Indian Affairs.

Plan of the Village of Rossville and the School Site.
Contour plan of the School Site and soundings for water intake and sewer outlet.
Plan showing location of sewers and profiles of River and Lake beds.

We also enclose a copy of a letter from Mr. G.B. Anderson, District Engineer to Mr. Blais with a copy of report from Professor G.H. Herriot, D. & M.L.S.

The School site as shown on the plans is that proposed by this Division when the development was to consist of six buildings similar in design to those proposed for the Teslin Residential School. Since then the scheme has been considerably modified and a site of the area shown is probably no longer necessary.

Nevertheless, with the plans and information now available to us, the design of any future project can be done expeditiously, with unknown factors practically eliminated.

In his letter covering the submission of plans, Mr. Blais states that when accounts for the investigation are received, they will be passed to us for payment. In this connection when the matter of carrying out this work was discussed with Indian Affairs, by our Chief Architect, it was arranged that since no funds were available to us for work at Norway House, the cost of the investigation would be borne by Indian Affairs.

Accordingly when the accounts reach us, they will be sent to that Branch for payment.

Enclosure.

February 25th, 1949.

Hon. James A. MacKinnon,
Minister of Mines and Natural Resources,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Mr. MacKinnon:

It is very kind of you to write about what our Church has done at Muncey. We believe the policy followed is the right one. We are fortunate in having Rev. R.E. Joblin as Principal of the Consolidated School. We are grateful for the cooperation of the officers of your Department.

May I take this opportunity of drawing your attention to two matters of great importance.

(1) We greatly need the rebuilding of the Norway House Residential School. This was destroyed by fire three years ago. The officers of your Department can furnish you with the facts and with the figures which reveal the need of this School. I am sorry that I must point out that because this school is not in operation some of the Indians who are adherents of our Church are being induced to send their children to schools operated by the Roman Catholic Church. I do not wish to find fault with either the parents of the church but I do want to point out that the lack of a school is prejudicial to the interests of the United Church in the Norway House Agency.

(2) We are somewhat concerned about priorities in building or rebuilding Residential Schools. We had been given to understand by officers of your Department that the policy was that the first projects would be the rebuilding of schools which had been destroyed by fire and that only after these necessary and vital replacements had been cared for would new schools be undertaken.

It may be that the information I have is incorrect but I am informed that a new school is being erected at Teslin.
at a cost of $400,000. We would not deny the need of the Indians at this place but we want to assure you that we expected our needs at Norway House to have priority. I must leave the matter of replacements for other Churches to be dealt with by the proper persons in those churches. I am simply pointing out what the United Church expects.

I have given you my frank and honest opinion on these matters. I would much prefer to talk these things over but unfortunately my engagements are such that I cannot hope to be in Ottawa before Easter and I feel that these representations should be made immediately.

Yours sincerely,

Geo. Dorey.
OTTAWA, March 7, 1949.

Rev. George Dorsey, D.D.,
Secretary,
Board of Home Missions,
The United Church of Canada,
299 Queen St. West,
TORONTO 3B, Ontario.

Dear Doctor Dorsey:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of February 25, 1949, concerning the Norway House Residential School.

As you are no doubt aware, our Education officials have been giving a great deal of consideration to the educational needs of the Indians of the Norway House Agency. An inspection trip of the area made two years ago revealed that the day schools were in a very poor state of repair. Since then, we have completed two modern and well constructed day schools for children of your denomination at Island Lake and at Cross Lake. At the present time, we have two complete sets of materials for other day schools en route by tractor train to God's Lake Narrows and to Oxford House. Funds have been provided in our 1948-50 Estimates for the construction of these schools next summer.

With regard to the rebuilding of the Norway House Residential School, I may say that the necessary ground survey for this project was completed last summer by two surveyors who were employed by the Department of Public Works in connection with the proposed building of a hospital by the Indian Health Services Branch. Our Lands and Development Services Branch has been asked to prepare a set of drawings for the rebuilding of this school but, unfortunately, we have not been able to advise them specifically as to the size of the building...
which should be erected. Our inspectors reported that previously a considerable number of children from the immediate vicinity of Norway House attended the residential school when they could well have been attending day schools. It has been suggested that a day school be built across the Bay to provide educational facilities for the children there. It is claimed that this area has a stable population and that if a day school were erected there, few, if any, of the children would be taken to winter camp.

We appreciate the fact that inland from Norway House there are a number of reserves on which it is very difficult to successfully operate day schools, due to the conditions under which the Indians live. There is also the persistent problem of orphans and families with one or both parents in hospital for treatment for tuberculosis.

The pupilage at the former Norway House Residential School was 105. The problem now is to decide definitely the pupilage of the proposed new school. We had hoped to arrive at a definite answer following the recent visit of one of our officials, but, unfortunately, weather conditions prevented his landing at certain reserves on which there were Indians belonging to the United Church of Canada. You will appreciate the fact that the building of residential schools is today a very costly undertaking. Therefore, we must be careful in building a school which will suffice for our needs but will not be too large for the Indian population it is intended to serve. Naturally, we wish the children for whom day school facilities are provided to attend such schools and we do not wish them placed in a residential school in order to fill it. I would, therefore, like to hear from you as to the views of your local missionaries, and to receive statements from them as to the number of children of your Church in their various missions who actually require residential school care and education. We could then have this information reviewed by our officials.
I have noted your comments with regard to the Teslin Residential School. The need of a residential school at this point was brought to the attention of the department some ten years ago and assurances were subsequently given that construction would proceed once materials and labour became readily available. The welfare situation has been aggravated by conditions resulting from the presence of soldiers of the United States army and workers who were employed in the building of the Alaska Highway. Due to the unusually large number of welfare cases in the Teslin area, which require institutional care, the department feels that a residential school is an urgent necessity.

I should like to assure you, however, that the residential school requirements of the United Church of Canada at Norway House are being carefully borne in mind, provision having been made in the 1949-50 Estimates for the construction of the first unit of the new school, namely the classroom block.

Yours sincerely,

Jas. A. MacKinnon.

Dear Sirs:

Andrew Crate of Norway House brought me this petition and asked me to make a typewritten copy of this material. Aside from this I have had nothing to do with the petition which was produced entirely on the initiative of the Indians. I might add that in my opinion the list is hardly complete inasmuch as many were already away muskrating.

Although I had nothing to do with the petition I thoroughly agree with its contents and I do hope that plans for the Residential school are completed and that it will be started this year.

Aside from any theoretical considerations concerning which there seems to be considerable difference of opinion I fail to see how any one actually faced with many of the conditions up here could avoid the very practical conclusion that there is still a large segment of the Indian population whose educational needs can only be served in an adequate sense by some form of Residential School.

There have been a number of specific cases within this Agency where the education and moral welfare of the children concerned has been very definitely retarded and neglected entirely due to the absence of Residential school here and to the policy of either officials or department itself which too frequently has considered this problem (that is as to whether or not a child should go to Residential School or not) in terms of geography rather than of personality and environment. I know that in certain of these cases...
severe criticism would have resulted in an ordinary white community had the worst of these cases been allowed to just drift along in such conditions as their homes represented.

For these reasons I am more than happy to forward this petition to you on behalf of its authors.

Sincerely yours,

G.C. Johnson - Missionary
