Dear Sirs:

We the undersigned hereby ask the department's co-operation, by taking steps to rebuild the school which was destroyed by fire a few years ago.

Since the building was destroyed, through no one's neglect, we have realized, since then what benefits the school really had.

A lot of children have been deprived of good environments. Many parents would like to see their children again in such conditions that prevailed a few years ago. We appreciated the co-operation that the principals and staff gave to them.

Many parents have transferred their children to other Residential Schools. Some have even taken steps as to put them into schools under auspices of other denominations. For they realized that the school had great assets to them and their children.

They realized that the training their children were getting was excellent, both religiously and practically.

Many of the children who were much better off in a Residential School are now in poor homes, where the environment is indeed poor.

We look forward earnestly to the time, as soon as possible that the department will take steps to rebuild the school, so that our children will have the training that they now lack.

In support of which we sign our names.

Thanking you most kindly we remain,

Yours truly,

Ottawa, May 27, 1933.

Sir:

I have to refer you to official letter dated December 20th last, informing you of the appointment of Miss I. M. Faithful as teacher of the Shoal Lake Indian Day School as from January first, 1933, to succeed Mr. Francis Daniels, and stating that salary would be paid at the rate of $80 per teaching month, less 10% during the present fiscal year.

The Auditor general has taken exception to the granting of any increased salary rate over that previously paid and has pointed out that the spirit, if not the letter, of Order in Council of June 14th, 1932, further extended by Order in Council of April 3rd, 1933, has been violated by the Department in agreeing to pay Miss Faithful at the rate of $800 per teaching year, less 10%, as compared to $650 per teaching year, less 10%, paid her predecessor, Mr. Francis Daniels.

The paragraph in the Order in Council above referred to, which applies in this instance, reads as follows: "That no increase prior to March 31, 1934, be made in the remuneration of any officer, clerk or employee".

I regret, therefore, that salary can only be allowed Miss Faithful at the rate of $65 per teaching month, less 10% - this being the same rate as was paid Mr. Daniels, her predecessor. I would request that you inform Miss Faithful accordingly. Cheque in payment of salary due her for the quarter ended March 31st last, at the rate mentioned, will be sent by mail in your care, in the course of the next few days. His Lordship Bishop Burd, Prince Albert, is being informed regarding the salary that can be allowed Miss Faithful.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

S. Lovell, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

In reply to your letter dated the 18th, I have taken the liberty of writing you rather a long letter. I am an Englishman from the City of London, I was educated under Professor Henry of King's College, London, since leaving there I have followed the profession of surveyor of Wales, having served in the Pen and Pencil Company, Lord George Hamilton, Colonel Sir William Hewitt, General Stephenson, Lieutenant in different regiments, as well as have travelled to different countries. Finally, I landed here in Canada working in eastern Canada under Lieutenant-Colonel Robert Fulton, meeting the Hon. Mr. Justice of the State of Vermont, from whom I came West in the fall of 1870 until 1872 when I returned to England. I wrote to Mr. Justice Inspector McCall who asked me to go to a teacher to the mountain, then they were all gathered there. From the first I put my sons of Christ in my education to do well. I should be the blessed Master. I held with them people for 6 years, nothing up with the present hardships. My salary for year together was a dollar or two, I was paid $10.12. A bag for house flour, Indian style. Mr. Braden asked me to go to Dollar Lake, I do have been moved from one school to another, always travelling at my own expense and finding my own house to live in.
Inspector McCauley died unexpectedly. Marlett succeeded him, but the fact of my being strongly opposed to his views, Mr. Marlett did not get along very well. But Mr. Marlett himself got another hand and another better. Mr. Indian Agent Boulton has succeeded Mr. Reed. Even then appointed to Moore Lake, where it was very difficult work on account of the great amount of whisky being brought on the reserve by the infamous Hamilton. The immoral habits of the Indians kept me very busy fighting the devil. Mr. Boulton left Mr. Fisher took his place. Also a new Bishop taken the place of another of Mr. Bishop's name Bishop Pinkham. So now all my superiors were all new or me also a new Rural Dean came to see me. I have seen quite a number of changes. About this time I had some trouble with the Indian Chief at Moore Lake about drunk & lazy men, I have made some report of my work to Mr. Indian Agent Fisher & Mr. Fisher came to Moore Lake & investigated the matter & the chief was entirely defeated no other charge could be proved against him (the whole band stood by him & have proved good friends to me, all the time have a teacher they would deal like me to come back again) still Mr. Fisher recommended a change for me. The new Bishop did not like me but removed, but still I was ordered to go to Par Mowat again, so I hitch up my horse & left for
Short Lake Reserve

I arrived at the Pug two days after here. I had to buy a very large canoe & get fish when I started. The boat was very much loaded but all went well until we were in the 3rd Rapid between the Pug and Short Lake where the stream made a false start & the boatman became very excited. The boat swung against a rock & capsized, sufficient to say that my only daughter was lost. She was only 7 years old, so after she arrived at Short Lake in a very poor condition my wife was taken back & kept her bed all the winter & my children were almost starved. Mr. Agent Waddy forwards a request for an increase in salary to Francis J. Daniels, teacher of the Shoal Lake Indian Day School, The Pas Agency.

I have the honor to report that on December 7th I inspected the Shoal Lake Day School. The register showed 11 boys and 7 girls attending school. There were present at the time of my visit 9 boys and 6 girls. The average attendance for the December quarter up to the present time is 15.

The school is kept very tidy and the Indians have supplied lots of wood and there are at least 8 cords of wood piled outside the school.

I examined the various classes and there were 4 boys and 2 girls in the beginners class, who could count and repeat the alphabet and spell simple words. In standard One there were 4 boys and 2 girls who could multiply, subtract, add and divide in arithmetic, and could read quite well from the book one. They could also give English names and descriptions for any articles in use in the school. In Standard two there were 2 girls, who were very good in arithmetic and could also do simple fractions. They were getting along well in writing and spelling etc. There was only one boy in Standard three. He was not much further advanced than the two girls in standard two. I am well satisfied with the standing of the pupils in the school.

I am, Sir,

Your obedient servant

Dear Sir:

Mr. Francis Daniels, teacher at Shoal Lake, in the Pas Agency, has asked for a change of work after Christmas and has accepted the school run by the Church of England at Chitek Lake in the Carlton Agency. The Indians at that Reserve will not send their children to school unless they have a Cree-speaking teacher, and I think he will make a success of that school. At present 13 children are attending. This leaves a vacancy at Shoal Lake and I beg to nominate for this post Miss Margaret Faithfull, who has done such excellent work at Little Pines Reserve for many years. She found the large school with the higher grades too much for her health and needed a holiday. But now, after a rest, she feels equal to the smaller school with lower grades. I think she will be invaluable at Shoal Lake and she will help in the project of the nursing shelter at that point. I shall be glad to know what salary you will allow her. She will not receive any remuneration from the Church.

MEMORANDUM,

SCHOOL BRANCH:

With reference to your application for the issue of a cheque in favour of Miss T. M. Faithful, covering March quarter salary at teacher at the Shoal Lake Indian Day School, I beg to point out that in my opinion, the salary if not the letter of Order-in-Council P. C. 44/1932 of June 14th, 1932 (extended by P. C. 51/1933 of April 1st, 1933) has been violated by the Department in agreeing to pay Miss Faithful $800.00 per teaching year as compared to $650.00 paid her predecessor Mr. Francis Daniels.

The paragraph in the Order-in-Council above referred to which applies in this instance reads as follows:

"That no increase, prior to March 31st, 1933, be made in the remuneration of any officer, clerk or employee, except on promotion under the conditions prescribed by the next succeeding paragraph."

While Miss Faithful may not have received an increase in salary, there is undoubtedly an increase proposed in the salary for the position of teacher at the Shoal Lake School.

It is also our contention that as the authority for the appointment of Day School teachers has been transferred from the Civil Service Commission to the Department, that all new appointments should be approved by the Deputy Superintendent General. The approval in the case of Miss Faithful is only implied from the letter of December 20th, 1932, addressed to the Rt. Rev. W. T. Hallam, D.D., and is not considered sufficient.

In view of the foregoing, this office does not feel justified in issuing a cheque to Miss Faithful at a rate in excess of $650.00 per school year which was the rate paid her predecessor.

The application is, therefore, returned herewith.

Representative of the Treasury.

Sir:

I beg to submit the following report of my work and activities on the Reserve during the months of April, May, June and July.

The school attendance was not very good from April 16th until June 8th, on account of the bridge across the river being washed away with the ice. The river was very high and the current swift, so the children could not get across alone.

The Treaty Party arrived June 13th and we had a busy and happy time.

The Indians are in fairly good health and circumstances. Most of the men are away now cutting hay, and some of the men are up the lake for fall fishing.

Robert Gott, #41 died on Sunday July 29th with heart failure.

Dr. Medd paid a visit to the Reserve, July 19th. While here he paid a visit to Birch River Reserve, making the trip by canoe. He left here Sunday, the 22nd. He did not find any cases of serious illness. But quite a number were suffering with their teeth which kept him busy pulling teeth.

We had our Annual Picnic, the last day of school. Races, football and games, also a canoe race made it a very pleasant day. The weather being perfect so all had a very good time.

Your obedient servant

E.J. Cooke,
Assistant Teacher

Dear Sir,

With reference to your telegram to the Bishop of Saskatchewan, dated Sept. 25th., re Miss Faithfull, Teacher at Shoal Lake Indian Day School; I visited Shoal Lake last week, and Mrs. Lowe, wife of the Teacher at Red Earth came with me to nurse Miss Faithfull if she needed nursing.

We found Miss Faithfull considerably better, and she was delighted to find there was a white woman within reach who could come to her in case of need.

During the four days we were there, she picked up wonderfully, and opened the school again on Oct. 12th. 2nd.

She now feels able to stay for the present, and carry on the work.

The Bishop has communicated with more than one teacher, but so far we have not found anyone whom we think would carry on the work as well as Miss Faithfull. Not only has she an almost perfect attendance at the school, and is helping the children to make real progress, but her influence for good is making a splendid impression on the whole Reserve.

The Bishop therefore recommends not making another nomination, at any rate till the Christmas holidays, and we can see by then how Miss Faithfull's health is.

She has written to Mr. Indian Agent Lovell saying that she feels able to carry on if it is in the best interests of the school and people that she should do so.

Yours faithfully,

W. L. J. Paul.

Dear Sir,

Re Shoal Lake Indian Day School.

This will confirm my night lettergram of today's date saying that we have been unable to find a suitable male Teacher for above school. We communicated with those who applied for a school this year, and advertised for a Teacher, but those we thought would be suitable have already signed on for a school for this term.

Shoal Lake would not be a very suitable place for a young unmarried lady Teacher.

Accordingly, I communicated with Mrs. Stanley Read of Livelong, who, as Miss Amy Wrigley, was so successful in teaching the Thunderchild Day School. And I have received word today that she is willing to take this position if the Department approves. She applied before for the Thunderchild School, but as there were many unmarried Teachers needing a position at that time, she was not offered the post.

I suggested that Mr. Read, who is a mechanic, might get employment with the Poe Lumber Co. which is working in the neighbourhood of Shoal Lake, and so be near Mrs. Read, without living on the Reserve. Failing this he might stay at Livelong where he and his brother have a garage.

As far as the work goes, and the welfare of the Indians, I knew of none who I think would do as well as Mrs. Read, and as the only answer to our advertisement was from another married lady, I do not think we are doing any wrong to other teachers in offering her the position.

Miss Faithfull's health broke down there. I found her very ill at the nearest neighbour's five miles from Shoal Lake on Sunday Oct. 4th. I had tried to bring in my car via Nipawin 100 miles away, and 60 of those miles over trails which most people would call impassable for a car, hoping to give her an easier journey out than by waggons. When I saw her condition and the condition of the trails, I at once saw it was out of the question for her to attempt such a journey. Yet something had to be done. Fortunately there is a stretch of the Carrot River which is straight and deep. So I sent out a message to the Mac G. Aviation Co., Prince Albert, to send in a plane. In this way Miss Faithfull was safely taken out to civilisation, and is now taking medical treatment in Saskatoon.

But there is a bill due to the Aviation Co. of $56.00. I have guaranteed this payment, but if the Department could see its way to pay for this necessary air journey, I should be very grateful.

But, apart from this, would it not be possible to raise the Teacher's salary to, say $75 per teaching month, and have the house made reasonably warm for winter use, with storm doors and windows, and have a well dug.

I should then find it much easier to apply to a fully qualified Teacher to take up the work at Shoal Lake.

I had arranged for Mrs. Read, if she had been appointed, in the first place to go in with me by car; and then when I did not hear from the Department, to come in by the plane which took Miss Faithfull out. It was not till my return to Prince Albert that I received your letter telling of the ruling that under no circumstances could a married lady teacher be appointed.

I should be glad to hear from you, as to what offer the Department would make to Mr. Richford, and whether they would approve of his appointment if I can persuade him to go.

I knew of a young unmarried man who might accept the school, but I do believe a woman like Mrs. Richford, who would have the welfare of the Indians at heart, would be a very great asset on the Reserve. The young girls on the Reserve need a woman to look after them.

I am, Sir,

Dear Sir,

Re Shoal Lake Indian Day School.

I am in correspondence with a Teacher who I believe would be suitable in every way for above school.

He is Mr. Willis A. Richford, who is teaching who is teaching Crescent Hill School, near Kinistino, Sask. He has been there six years, so evidently gives satisfaction.

He has permanent second, and interim first class certificate.

He has had eleven years teaching experience in Saskatchewan.

He taught a school at Meadow Lake composed mainly of Cree children.

He has also had experience of teaching English to non-English speaking children in a Swedish settlement.

He is 31 years of age, married with one child.

I have heard from two clergyman who know him, and they heartily recommend him both as to character and teaching ability.

Now there is the other side of the proposition, and Mr. Richford has not yet definitely consented to go to Shoal Lake if the appointment is approved.

It is a case of asking a married man with a child to go to a place 75 miles from a Doctor, 45 miles from a Post Office, with no white neighbours, ten miles from the nearest store, no road except in winter; one and a half miles from a river which this fall became too shallow for navigation by canoe to the Pas.

The water supply is a creek ½ mile from the teacherage.

The house has one room upstairs and one downstairs, but it is in poor repair, draughty and cold in winter with a home-made door and no storm door, no storm windows and no well.

And to the teacher who is willing to put up with all this hardship and inconvenience the Department offers a salary of something under $700 a year for teaching and giving out the rations.
Ottawa, November 5, 1936.

Venerable Sir:

I have your letter of the 27th ultimo, regarding the services of a teacher for the Shoal Lake Indian Day School. It is noted that you are endeavouring to arrange with Mr. Willis A. Richford, a qualified teacher, to take the position.

In the event of Mr. Richford accepting the Department would be pleased to approve his appointment. We would be prepared to allow him salary at the rate of $75 a teaching month - this being an increase of $10 per month over the rate previously paid. I shall be pleased to hear from you definitely, at an early date, stating whether Mr. Richford accepts and, if so, the date on which he begins duties.

The Department is authorizing Mr. Lovell, Indian Agent, The Pas, to have the teacher's residence supplied with a storm door and storm windows and to carry out any other minor repairs that may be necessary to make the building as comfortable as possible. I regret that it will not be possible, under present regulations, to pay the transportation costs of Miss Faithful, the former teacher, or of her successor, in proceeding to the school. The account which you submitted is herewith returned.

Dear Mr. Lovell,

I am writing to you with regard to Miss Faithful, who has been seriously ill in Saskatoon Hospital.

When she left Shoal Lake in October, she had enough money to carry her through the winter, and as the Bishop of Saskatoon had offered her a school in the Spring, she thought all would be well. But she had to go to hospital three times during the winter. She was able to pay the bill on the first two occasions, but the bill for the last visit, which was the longest, amounts to just over $80.00 and there are doctors' fees for treatment in addition.

I wrote to Dr. D.K. Balsan, Macmillan Building, Saskatoon about her condition, and he replied that there is no way of telling when she might expect one of the embarrassing and sometimes serious attacks of asthma, and that it would be very unsafe for her to assume a position where medical assistance is not readily available; and under the circumstances it would be very much better for her to be retired.

Miss Faithful herself feels that she is not in a fit state of health to take up work for the present.

Now we come to the question of what happens when a Government employee who is not on a pension fund, breaks down in health, spends all her money on hospital bills, and still needs further treatment, and also something to live on. There are friends who would be pleased to give her hospitality for some time, but at present she has to continue the treatment in Saskatoon.

Do you think the Department of Indian Affairs, would pay the hospital bills?

When nominating her successor at Shoal Lake, I told the Department about the necessity of sending her out by airplane, and enclosed the bill. But they evidently thought I ought to pay it, as I sent for the plane. So I paid it, and I am glad I did this, as I think getting her to hospital easily and quickly, saved her life. One night in hospital, during this last attack, they did not think she would pull through the night. The plane cost $56.00. Now there is this $80.00 to be found somewhere.

I should be glad of your advice as to what is the best thing to do, and I should be grateful if you could see your way to urge the Department to help with the hospital bills.

Thanking you for whatever help you can give,

Yours faithfully,

(Signed) W.J. Paul.

P.S. I think the Department appreciate what Miss Faithful did at Little Pines Reserve, where she helped to build up one of the best Indian Day Schools in the Province. She worked there for many years.

Dear Sir:

I herewith beg to submit to you the name of Mr. J.K. Schunaman for the position of teacher at the Shoal Lake Indian Day School to succeed Mr. C.H. Wilde.

Mr. Schunaman's application is backed by most excellent recommendations from different inspectors and also from his present principal. He is just now teaching in the Gordon's Anglican Indian Residential School at Funnicky, Saskatchewan. In recommending him the Principal states:

"He has been with me here since 1932 which in itself is assurance of his capability. The Provincial Board Inspector, Mr. Moyer, has always spoken most favourably of his method in endeavouring to get the confidence of his pupils together with the firmness necessary more especially with the Indian child. Ottawa, Sept. 8th., 1911.

Right Reverend Sir,-

It has been reported to the Department that the building used for the school on the Red Earth Reserve is in a very dilapidated condition. The roof leaks and when it rains water drips all over the floor. Mortar is falling off the walls and there is no chimney; the stove pipe simply goes through the roof and is liable to cause the destruction of the building by fire at any time. There is neither porch nor double windows.

As Your Lordship is aware the Department pays an annual rental of $40.00 for this and also for the Shoal Lake and Moose Lake school buildings. The Shoal Lake building also requires repairs, and it is stated that this matter has been repeatedly brought to the attention of the Church authorities but that no action has been taken. I would ask Your Lordship to see that these buildings are put in such a state of repair that they will be at least habitable, as if this is not done the Department will be forced to discontinue the payment of any further rental.

Your obedient servant,

Ass't Deputy and Secretary.

Sir,

I beg to inform the Department that on our Annuity Payment trip I looked over the Lower Fairford Indian Day School carefully and found that there is no use repairing the school as the logs are very badly decayed. When the school was built it was plastered inside and outside while the logs were green and the result was that they decayed in half the time that they would have had they been dry. If anything is done it will have to be in the way of a new building.

If the Department entertain the idea of building a Boarding School at this point, there would be no need of a Day School. If not, I might say that this would be an excellent location for an improved Day School. Mr. Colin Sanderson, the present teacher, would not be able to take charge of such a school, but there ought to be no difficulty in getting suitable people to take charge as the school is only four miles from the Railway.

SHOAL LAKE, (Church of England)

The school building belongs to the Church of England, is built of logs and is in a very bad state of repair. There is a steep roof with no ceiling inside, and it is very cold in the winter. The roof leaks in several spots, and you can see daylight in a number of places. There are three windows, but no double windows or porch for the winter.

There is no chimney, but the stove pipe runs through the roof. This building in its present condition, is not fit for a school, and the Church of England should be notified to make the class-room habitable, as I understand they are receiving $10.00 a month for the use of the same.

Your obedient servant

Sir,

In connection with my report on Shoal Lake Day School I would recommend that a new school be built on this reserve. During treaty payments and at our band meeting the subject was brought up by Chief Albert Moore, and enlarged upon by several members of the band. They argued that the present building was unfit for school purposes, and I must uphold this argument. The building is log, and was built by the Church some 20 years ago. The roof is poor and daylight seen in many places. The Indians will get out logs and build the walls free of charge if the Department will finish the building; $800.00 would be ample for this purpose. It would not be necessary to employ a contractor to finish as the Indians will be able to do this.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

Replying to Department letter No. 117561-5 dated 3rd inst., regarding freighting lumber for schools to Shoal Lake and Red Earth, I beg to say that in writing about this I neglected to explain the reason why this lumber was not taken up last summer. First, the Carrot River was blocked up with the H.B.Railway ties, when water was sufficiently high for navigation. When the ties were cleared out the water had fallen so low that even our treaty launch could hardly get up. The Ross Navigation Co. who handle this freight did not get up the river at all, but sent some of the Indian Department supplies up by canoes. The rest was sent up by team this winter. All freight for the Hudson's Bay Co. was taken up by team this winter as they could not get it up by boat. I mention this to show that the fault was neither the Transportation Company's nor mine. The lumber therefore could not be taken up and is still here in store.

The Indians asked me for this work which would be the means of helping them along this hard winter. It will cost more, freighting it in winter, but we may be up against the same proposition next summer, as there is very little snow this winter.

I trust therefore that the Department will allow this work to be done by the respective bands.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Mr. Pegeat,

Mr. Agent Waddy requests that four double desks be supplied for the use of the Shoal Lake Indian Day School. He states that there is an overflow of children and the present seating accommodation is not sufficient. The desks at present in use at the school are manufactured by The Canadian Office and School Furniture Co., Limited, Preston, Ont., and he asks that a similar type of desk be supplied. The Canadian Office and School Furniture Co. have quoted prices.

The desks required are known as double entire, size No. 4, and the price quoted by the above firm is $11.05 each, f.o.b. Preston, less a discount of 5%, and freight from Preston, Ont., to The Pas, Manitoba.

I shall be pleased to be informed whether the order for these four desks may be given to the above firm. The total cost would be $44.20, less 5%, and freight added. These desks could, no doubt, be shipped in a knock down condition, which would save shipping space and freight charges, and they could be assembled and put together when they arrive at the school. If ordered, they should be shipped by freight to Mr. Agent Waddy, The Pas.

Funds can be provided from the vote for Indian Education.

INSPECTOR'S OFFICE

WINNIPEG, MAN., July 9th, 1935.

SHOAL LAKE INDIAN DAY SCHOOL
THE PAS AGENCY

Sir:

I visited this school on Tuesday, June 4th, 1935. Miss L. M. Faithful is the teacher and she has done excellent work since her appointment two years ago. There are 15 on the roll and the grades are as follows:

Grade I - 2
II - 2
IV - 3
V - 6

The attendance has been excellent and the pupils are well along in their respective grades.

The school is a log building and is in fair condition. The equipment is very scant; in fact, there is a shortage of desks and seats. Two seats and two desks are needed. The blackboard space is too limited. They have only one piece 4x8 ft. There is plenty of wall space for three more pieces, 4x6 ft. long and, if possible, this should be supplied.

The children were well dressed, clean, and all had their hair neatly combed.

Your obedient servant,

A. G. Hamilton

Ottawa, November 5, 1936.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in communication with the church authorities, regarding the obtaining of a teacher for the Shoal Lake Indian Day School, to succeed Miss Faithful, who has given up duties on account of ill health. It is hoped to obtain an early nomination from the church authorities, and you will be advised of the name, salary, etc., of the teacher appointed.

The Department's attention has been drawn to the condition of the teacher's residence. This house has one room upstairs and one downstairs and is in poor repair; draughty and cold in winter, with a home-made door and no storm door or storm windows.

I would request that you will arrange, as soon as possible, to have a storm door and storm windows made and installed on this building. Further, you may carry out any minor repairs considered necessary in order to make the building as comfortable as possible. No unnecessary expense should be incurred. Please forward itemized accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of the work considered necessary by you.

There is no well at this school. It is considered too late in the season to arrange for digging a well, but you might bring this matter to the attention of the Department early next spring. At that time, you should give full information as to how you would advise the work be carried out and, if possible, the approximate cost.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

S. Lovell, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

The Pas, Man.,
June 23rd, 1937.

Dear Sir,

I would like to bring to your attention the condition of the school teacher's residence at Shoal Lake.

It is a very old log building, is rotten and full of vermin. It is impossible to do anything with it. The teacher Mr. C.E. Wilde is going to get married, I understand, during the holidays and wishes to bring his wife back to Shoal Lake, and he would like to know if there is any possibility of having a house built for him. I do not suppose this is possible, as you have previously stated there are no funds for other articles asked for.

I would suggest the building the Department built for a Hospital and which has never been used be turned into a teacher's residence. It could be fixed up fairly well for $100.00. Could I have authority to do this? I might say that the teacher is at the present time living in the Hospital, as the residence is not fit to live in.

Your obedient servant,

Samuel Lovell
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

It is with great regret that I am reporting the unfortunate loss. The building which we were using (the hospital) for a classroom was razed to the ground this afternoon at approximately 12:45 p.m. this day November 27th.

The moving of the classroom was agitated by the band due to the considered unsound condition of the present school building. It has decided that no further steps be taken for repairing the building and the moving of the classroom to another building until your arrival and pending your judgment. Another meeting was held two weeks ago about the school and your arrival unforeseen. It was decided that the band put free labor on the hospital building regarding necessary repairs and the moving of the classroom over. This was done on...
On Saturday, November 18th,
I considered the motive behind
this was good and consented to the
idea but not after awaited your
arrival. I did not write to notify
you of the change because we were
expecting you any day but when
it got colder the change was made.
The building was certainly covered.
The old school building will
have to be braced in some way
or another if it is to be in further
service.

The majority of the readers
and the library was lost. Even
double desks and the teacher's desk
could not be saved also the black-
boards.

I have enough readers and
books with scribblers and pens
to carry me through for the year
but the desks and blackboards
will be missed.

We will be awaiting your
arrival.

Yours Truly,

S. Atkinson
The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

I am enclosing herewith a report received from the Rev. S. Atimoyoo, the teacher at Shoal Lake Indian Day School.

The building they had been using for a class-room was burned down on November 27th and with it most of the school equipment, including desks, blackboard, books, etc. This building that was burned down was one that was built some years ago to be used as a Hospital building for Indians of the Band who were sick. It was never used much for that purpose. They were using it as a classroom as they considered the old school room was in such a bad condition that it was dangerous and might fall down and injure someone at any time. However, since the "hospital building" has burned down, I have had them move back into the old school room, which I have had braced. With this bracing and the cold weather I do not think there is any danger at all until Spring. This building is absolutely done and we must have a new building next year if we are to carry on at all. A classroom has been requisitioned for in the estimates.

It will however be necessary to get the lumber and material on the ground during the winter if we are to build as soon as the fine weather arrives and we should also cut the logs this winter and move them to the building site. It will be practically impossible to transport either the logs or material after the warm weather comes. The Shoal Lake area is mostly swamps, the river is shallow and transportation during the summer months very difficult and practically impossible most of the time.

I would like you to send me $100.00 accountable cheque in order to pay for the logs and would also request the material be bought as soon as possible so that it can be freighted to the site during the cold weather.

S. Lovell, Indian Agent.

Ottawa,
December 28, 1944.

Mr. S. Lovell, Indian Agent, The Pas, Man.

I have your letter of the 18th instant, with reference to the Shoal Lake Indian Day School. It is noted that the building being used for school purposes was destroyed by fire and that the old school is again being used.

I realize from your letter the present condition of the Shoal Lake School, but at the present time I cannot see my way clear to promise definitely that we will be able to replace it next summer. If you forward a list of the materials that would be required, the matter will receive further consideration. In sending this list you should intimate if the materials can be purchased locally and, if so, the name and address of the person from whom they might be secured. I would also like to have an estimate of the amount required for labour. In the meantime you are being forwarded a cheque for $100 for the purchase of logs but, as stated above, it should be understood that we are not definitely promising a new school next year. This is due to conditions of which you are fully aware.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

In reply to your letter 128-10-5, dated the 23rd ultimo, in connection with building a new school house at Shoal Lake.

A list of materials required to build the school house was attached to the 1945-46 Estimates, in duplicate.

I cannot express in too strong terms, the condition of this school. It is certainly not fit to live in and further it is so old and rotten that nothing could be done to improve it. The bottom logs are absolutely rotten. It is out of shape and if we tried to jack it up to put in new bottom logs the whole building would collapse. In fact I am afraid it might collapse anyway when the frost gets out of the ground. I have put braces up to prevent this. The Church authorities have inspected the school and are pressing for something to be done.

I am aware of the difficulty of getting new construction, owing to the war. I can see no other way out of this difficulty. We will either have to provide a building or close this Day School.

In the meantime, in accordance with your instructions I will buy the logs and get them on the ground. The material, as I mentioned in my previous letter must be freighted in during the winter, consequently must be purchased during the next six weeks, otherwise I do not think I could get it in.

S. Lowell,
Indian Agent.

Extract from letter from Mr. Ostrander dated June 21st, 1948. Original on file 107-9-1.

I examined the classroom and teacherage at the Red Earth Reserve. The classroom is an old log building and certainly no credit to the Department. The teacherage is very small, difficult to heat, and would not attract any teacher. School attendance is poor, partly because the school is situated at a point which is surrounded by water a great part of the year, and many of the children cannot reach the school for long periods because of the water, and partly because the Indians are trappers and do not seem to be much interested in education.

I did not visit the Shoal Lake Day School as I was informed that it was closed, but Mr. J.R. Bell, in charge of the Sipaskat Rat Project, who resides at Red Earth, informed me that conditions at Shoal Lake are even worse than at Red Earth.

Both of these points are so situated that the erection of classrooms and teaching quarters at the two places is out of the question at the present time because of the cost.
June 28, 1948.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 6th instant an amount of $1000.00 is provided in our current year's appropriation for an addition to the Shoal Lake Indian Day School but it is hoped that the necessary accommodation can be provided at a smaller cost.

I presume that this addition can be erected by day labour employing Indians. Will it be necessary to engage any white men? If so, please let me know what tradesmen will be necessary. An estimate of the cost of the labour should also be supplied. Full details should be furnished regarding the materials as these will have to be ordered through the Purchasing Agent. If any of the material can be purchased close to the school you should state the name of the firm and their address in order that we can give this information to the Purchasing Agent. At the same time you should let me know the best method of shipping the material to the school.

Yours truly,

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Shoal Lake Indian Day School
The Pas Agency, Electoral District of Nelson.

In the current year's appropriation an amount of $1000.00 was provided for an addition to the above school.

The Indian Agent advises that a frame addition should be erected.

Indians will be employed to do the rough work under the supervision of a white foreman. In this connection the Agent writes as follows:

"It would be more expensive and unsuitable to hire a contractor. I want a white man who understands log construction—a fairly good carpenter. I would appreciate if I were given authority to pick out a suitable man to supervise the Indians and work as a carpenter on this job."

I should appreciate if the Honourable the Minister would approve the construction of this building and, in that event, the attached purchase requisitions for material might be forwarded to the Purchasing Agent.

I should also appreciate receiving your instructions regarding the employment of the foreman.

Acting Director.
EX'D.

Ottawa,
September 2, 1936.

Dear Sir:

With further reference to your letter of July 26 regarding the erection of a residence at the Shoal Lake Indian Day School I enclose purchase order covering the hardware required. An order has been placed with the Monarch Lumber Company who have submitted the lowest tender of $548.97.

The following expenditures have, therefore, been authorized:

Lumber ........................................... $ 548.97
Hardware ........................................... 68.94
Logs (see letter Aug. 3) .................. 35.00

As you were previously informed $1000.00 was provided in the current year's appropriation for this building and in view of the expenditures already authorized there is a balance of $347.09 for wages. In view of the information contained in your letter of May 23 this amount should be ample.

With reference to the white foreman-carpenter you should employ Mr. Jos. Poirer, The Pas, Manitoba. As soon as you are ready to commence work you should apply for an accountable advance to cover the cost of the labour.

Yours truly,

S. Lovell, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
The Pas, Man.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training

I do not know if this branch will supply the cook stove and bed requested. Such articles have been supplied in some instances in the past.

I do not see any reason why Mr. Halkett could not supply these furnishings himself. I am doubtful if he will do so.

Regarding the water tank, this should be supplied. Water has to be hauled for some distance. The tank is needed for storage purposes in the teachers residence.

The prices were quoted by a Prince Albert firm. It is assumed these prices would be much the same at Carrot River, nearest railway point to Shoal Lake. There will be delivery freight charges to be added to the purchase price.

E. S. Jones,
Superintendent, Indian Agency.

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 10th instant, with reference to the cheque for the salary due you as teacher of the Shoal River Indian Day School for the quarter ending March 31st, last.

In reply I beg to say that it is now ascertained that this cheque was, in error, addressed to you at Grand Rapids, Via Mafeking, Man., instead of to Pelican Rapids. The Postmaster at Grand Rapids is being requested that if this letter is at his office to re-address it and forward it to you. In the meantime the Department is making you an advance of $75.00 on your salary for the current quarter in order that you will not be put to any further inconvenience through not receiving your March quarter salary. The balance due for the current quarter will be sent you on receipt of your quarterly return of attendance. It is hoped that the March quarter cheque will reach you safely and it is regretted that the wrong address was placed on the envelope containing your March quarter cheque.

Your obedient servant

[Signature]

Ottawa, July 24, 1926.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 20th instant, with reference to the appointment of Mrs. C. E. Cooke to the position of assistant teacher at the Shoal River Indian Day School. I note that she has been doing good work among these Indians in the capacity of field matron, and I am pleased to inform you that the Department will allow her a salary of $30 per teaching month. You will please explain to her that she has been appointed assistant teacher and outline her duties, which, of course, are to be those of field matron. In your official correspondence please refer to her as an assistant teacher, as it is in this manner that she is being classified. She should submit a monthly report to you in connection with her work.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKensie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

A. Ogletree, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Portage la Prairie,
Man.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 10th of January last and enclose herewith report on building data form, Shoal River Reserve.

The type of school erected at Little Saskatchewan Reserve last year, I consider ideal, and suitable for reserves. I have only a faint idea of the cost. The cost would be greater at an outlying place like Shoal River as freight is expensive. I beg to suggest that the freighting be contracted for. During the early spring a number of boats are tied up at the north end of the lake, awaiting for the ice to disappear and it is usually the middle of June before they make the trip to Winnipegosis. I believe the fishermen would be pleased to get work during this slack season.

I wish to call the department's attention to the resident missionary's statement, that the school is built on Mission lands. He claims that the Mission property covers 42 acres. This land is the only logical place to build a school. It is high, dry and sandy, close to the river.

There are 22 Indians at school at the present time. During the winter months the attendance is increased by halfbreeds whose parents come in to fish; the attendance last winter totaled 36. I have estimated the pupilage at 35; it is very doubtful if the Indian child population will ever go over these figures.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your recent letter enclosing building data form in connection with the proposed erection of a new day school on the Shoal River Reserve.

I note that you suggest the same type of school as was erected at Little Saskatchewan Reserve. In this connection I may say that reports reaching the Minister's office indicate that some of the local people consider the Little Saskatchewan school too elaborate and too expensive for the district. Under these circumstances the Department does not wish to incur the same criticism in the event of erecting a school at Shoal River.

I note that you suggest erection of the school by contract. This would probably mean that the school would cost as much as the Little Saskatchewan school.

Is there any small saw mill close to the Shoal River school where the necessary lumber could be secured and thus avoid the cost of freighting which you state is quite expensive? In this event it might be possible for the school to be built by day labour in charge of a competent white foreman, employing Indians to do the other work.

You mention in the last paragraph of your letter that there are only 28 Indian children in the school at the present time and you also refer to the halfbreeds who attend the school during the winter. As you are

J. Waite, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Portage la Prairie, Man.
aware this Department has no obligation to provide school facilities for halfbreeds. I am not certain from your letter whether in mentioning the pupilage of 35 you refer to Indian children only or to both Indians and halfbreeds. The 1934 census stated that there were 46 children between 7 and 16 years of age on the Shoal River Reserve and 40 children under 7 years of age. If these figures were correct it is quite possible that the Indian school population at the present time would be approximately 35 or even more.

I note that you suggest erection of a school on land owned by the Anglican Church. Present regulations will not permit our approving this recommendation. It would be advisable for you to see the Church authorities and ascertain if they are prepared to convey to us, free of charge, sufficient land as a site for this school.

In view of the contents of this letter you should reconsider very carefully what procedure should be taken with regard to the erection of a school at Shoal River and forward to me a complete report at your earliest convenience. At the same time you might state when you last visited this Reserve.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Mr. J. Waite,
Indian Agent,

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 29th ultimo, and wish to advise that I have heard no outside criticism of the school erected at Little Saskatchewan. I admit the school is very striking, and possibly does not conform to the generally accepted opinion of an Indian Reserve. In building a school at Shoal River, I strongly recommend a full basement and furnace. The basement is excellent if the teacher holds sewing classes or classes in manual training. It is also very useful for serving mid-day meals and can also be used as a play room on very severe days during the winter months. Some saving could be made in making the cloak rooms smaller and dispensing with the teachers' room altogether.

On the 27th ultimo I forwarded a letter received from one Mr. Glen Burrell of Mafeking, who will be operating a small saw mill approximately 20 miles from the reserve. Mr. Burrell is a fisherman during the fall and winter months, has a large boat for the freighting of the lumber, and is, I believe, a reliable man. A great saving would be made in the purchase of local lumber.

The Indians of this reserve are backward, although I believe the employment of a white foreman from the outside, and the employment of Indians for labouring would be cheaper.

There are 22 treaty Indian children attending school at the present time, and there will be an increase of the pupilage next fall term, and if no children are taken into residential school the attendance will approximate 30 next winter. All these will be treaty children.

Re: Shoal River Indian Day School

Dear Sir:

May I refer to your letter of the 12th ultimo, in which you submit, for departmental consideration, the quotation received by you from Mr. Glen Burrell of Mafeking, for the supply of lumber necessary to construct the above noted school.

Your recommendations with respect to the construction of this school have been carefully reviewed, and it has been decided to undertake the construction of the building by day labour, under the direction of a capable carpenter foreman. It is understood, of course, that Indian labour to the fullest extent possible will be used.

I am anxious, therefore, that you should take immediate steps to arrange for the construction of this school. You are authorized to engage Mr. William Poulsen, of Swan River, Manitoba, as foreman carpenter, and to consult Mr. Wm. Morrison, of Mafeking, Manitoba, with respect to any additional white labour that may be required.

I have secured from the Surveys and Engineering Branch a copy of certain plans which may prove helpful to the man in charge of construction. It is just possible, of course, that he may have to depart from the plans in certain particulars to meet local conditions. I feel confident, however, that you will experience little difficulty in establishing a school to meet the needs of the Indian population on the reserve.

The sum of $4,000 is included in the estimates of this year for the construction of this school. If it is at all possible, I should like to see expenditures kept to this amount. The plans will be sent forward under separate cover.

Yours truly,

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER:

Re: Shoal River Indian Day School, Manitoba.

Provision has been made in the 1939-40 estimates for the construction of an Indian day school on the Shoal River reserve, Manitoba, at an estimated cost of $4,000.

This reserve is situated approximately 25 miles north of Mafeking and has an Indian population of 223. Indian Agent Waite, in a letter dated July 12, states:

"I am now advised by Mr. Glen Burrell of Mafeking that he can supply all the necessary lumber for the construction of this school."

Mr. Burrell, I understand, operates a local sawmill comparatively close to the reserve.

In view of these circumstances, I recommend, for the approval of the Minister, that the construction of this school be undertaken by day labour, under the direction of a capable carpenter foreman and that Indian labour to the fullest extent possible be employed. I recommend, also, that the Agent be authorized to purchase the necessary lumber from Mr. Glen Burrell, whose quotation on the supply of lumber necessary is substantially lower than the price this Branch would be compelled to pay, should it be decided to ship lumber into the district from outside sources of supply.

Director.

DEPUTY HEAD
I beg to acknowledge receipt of Department letter dated the 11th instant, also plans of a day school, Shoal River Reserve, received on the 25th. In reply to the letter I beg to report that I interviewed Mr. Poulson at Swan River on the 28th and 30th and he is ready to start work constructing the school as soon as the materials are on the job. I proceeded to Mr. Burrell's on the 29th, and had to wait until 7.30 in the evening for Mr. Burrell to return from fishing. He then informed me that he had received no order for lumber from the Department and had recently sold all his lumber to outside firms. He claims to have 125,000 feet of lumber in the bush. This he intends to saw into lumber sometime next month, but this would not be properly seasoned until next mid-summer. To ship in lumber would be a very expensive proposition, as the nearest point would be Swan River and this would mean trucking to the Red Deer River and boat freight from there to Shoal River. I beg to suggest that the building of this school be held over until next year. This would allow the material to be purchased during the coming winter, and freighted on ice to the building site. This would be the cheapest form of freighting. It is my opinion that Burrell, although honest, is not entirely reliable, and any dealings the Department have with him should be in such form that the lumber will be delivered on the job at a specified time. The lumber business, with him, is a side line and unless held to a delivery date the material would be delivered at his convenience. On my return to Swan River I informed Mr. Poulson that the material was not on the job, and

Sir,

New Indian Day School at the Shoal River Reserve.

Reference telegram dated the 7th inst., I beg to advise that owing to the distance and inconvenience of the journey to Shoal River, I proceeded to Winnipeg on the 8th to the offices of the Monarch Lumber Coy.

The estimate shows net cost of material F.O.B. Mafeking $1761.20 also additional freight costs to the Red Deer River of $25.00. This includes paint for the building.

I am writing Mr. Burrell at Mafeking for a freight quotation from Mafeking to the Shoal River Reserve. This will be forwarded as soon as received. Mafeking is the last siding on the line convenient to railroad freight. From that point truck freighting will be necessary to the Red Deer River and from there by boat to Shoal River.

I am also writing Mr. Poulson informing him that the building of the school will be proceeded with this year. Mr. Poulson submitted two names, Sam Dubray as assistant carpenter and Mack Hunter as painter. These names are being submitted to Mr. Morrison at Mafeking for approval.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent

I can haul it for fifteen dollars a trip from Bowman to my wharf and I can take it from there to Shoal River for one hundred and twenty dollars. September 22, 1939.

Sir,

Re: 126-11-5

I beg to refer to my letter of the 11th instant, and enclose herewith a letter received from Mr. Glen Burrell, this date, in connection with the freighting of materials for the erection of the school, Shoal River Reserve.

Since my letter of the 11th, I have learned that the Red Deer River at the wharf is too shallow for power boats, and the only dredged channel is at Burrell's wharf. This wharf is approximately 26 miles from Mafeking.

On receipt of Mr. Burrell's letter I telephoned the Monarch Lumber Company and they agree to freight the material by truck from Mafeking to Burrell's dock at the price quoted i.e., $1786.20. This is a much better price than that quoted by Burrell.

I beg to suggest, that if the Monarch Lumber Company's tender is accepted the material be hauled to Burrell's dock and then transported from there by Burrell at his tender of $120.00. The boat will only be able to dock at the mouth of the Shoal River and there will be an additional cost of Indian freighting from the mouth of the Shoal River to the Mission. A distance of approximately one and a half miles.

I beg to attach hereto a sketch showing the route which will give some idea of the freighting problem.

With further reference to my letter of the 11th, I enclose herewith a letter received recently from one J.D. Houston which is self explanatory.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA.

Your obedient servant

DEPUTY MINISTER

In memorandum to the Deputy Minister dated August 11, 1939, it was recommended that the construction of the Shoal River school be commenced as soon as possible. This memorandum stated that the lumber could be secured from Mr. Glen Burrell.

A later report from the Agent stated that Mr. Burrell could not supply the lumber and consequently a quotation was obtained from the Monarch Lumber Company. They offered to supply all the material required, f.o.b. Mafeking, at a price of $1766.20.

Indian Agent Waddy considers this price reasonable and recommends its acceptance.

In order that the school may be erected at the earliest possible date I should appreciate receiving approval for placing the business with the Monarch Lumber Company.

Director.

The Department of Natural Resources, Canada Indian Affairs Branch, Portage La Prairie, Manitoba

Dear Sirs;

Re: Shoal Lake Indian School

We had a letter from our Manager at Bowsman, who is looking after the shipment of this material to Mr. Burrell's dock, stating that the cement, shiplap and some 2x4's for forms has been delivered so far, and now has been advised by Mr. Burrell that this material cannot be transported until after freeze-up, when it can be taken in over the ice. He is asking that we hold up delivery of the material to his dock, until such time as he can transport this material over the ice.

We will be glad to co-operate with Mr. Burrell and yourselves in anyway possible in connection with the delivery of this material.

However, we wish to point out that as soon as the snow blocks the highway, we will be unable to truck this material from Swan River or Bowsman to Mr. Burrell's dock. This highway will not be kept open for winter travel. We would suggest therefore, that if it is at all possible to store this material at Mr. Burrell's dock, that we be permitted to go ahead and complete the delivery of the material, so it will be at the dock when freeze-up comes and they can take it in over the ice.

We would be pleased to have your instructions in regard to the delivery of the balance of this material.

Yours very truly,

THE MONARCH LUMBER COMPANY LIMITED,

Per Albert Moore

Sir,

I beg to refer to your telegram dated the 3rd inst., authorizing the purchase of lumber for the Shoal River Day School.

The order was phoned to the Monarch Lumber Company the morning your telegram was received. On the 19th, I received the attached letter from the Monarch Lumber Company which is self-explanatory together with a telephone call from Mr. Burrell advising that the north end of the lake was frozen over and that freighting could not be done until after the ice had become solid. After receipt of the Monarch Lumber Company's letter it was suggested that immediate delivery of the material be made to Burrell's dock and arrangements were made with Mr. Burrell for the storage of the material until such time as the ice is thick enough to freight on.

Mr. Burrell advises me that most of the material will be stored under cover.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 23rd instant in which you state that it will be impossible to erect the Shoal River School before the end of March. The amount of $2000.00 which you have received to cover wages should be returned to the Department at once.

I note from your letter that the material is now being delivered to the Reserve. Please let me know what arrangements you have made to have it properly stored in order that none of it may be stolen.

At the present time I am not in a position to state whether or not funds will be available in our appropriation for the fiscal year 1940-41 to erect this building. Consequently it may be necessary to store the material for some time and, therefore, I will expect very definite information from you regarding the steps that you have taken to protect the material.

The Department cannot help but feel that if it had not been for the delay in your office this building would have been completed this year when funds were available. The first letter regarding this building was sent to you on January 10, 1939, and your reply to this letter did not reach the Department until March 27, over three months later. Considerable time was, therefore, lost which, if used, would have permitted the materials to be purchased at a much earlier date than they eventually were.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of Department letter dated the 26th instant re. the building of a school at the Shoal River Reserve. In reply I wish to advise that usually the north end of Lake Winnipegosis is not free of ice until around the 20th - 24th of May, and at the present time the ice is not safe to travel. I am in touch with the storekeeper at Pelican Rapids, and he will advise me as soon as the lake is free of ice. The site of the school has been decided upon. It is quite close to the old school. Some clearing of brush will have to be done, possibly one day's work.

June 8, 1940

I returned last night from the Shoal River Reserve, and wish to report that work on the excavation of the basement has commenced and will be practically completed by tonight. Mr. Poulson made the trip with me and will be returning to the reserve, with the treaty party, on the 16th. It is expected that the building will be finished by the end of July or the first week in August. I beg to make request that an accountable cheque for $500.00, to pay the cost of labour etc., reach me at Portage by Saturday, June 15th, otherwise an indefinite delay in the commencement of construction of the building will result, as labour will have to be paid for. The work of construction will be carried out by Mr. Poulson with the help of Indians. He expects to get along without the hiring of additional white help. His wages will be .80¢ per hour. The Indians will be paid at the rate of .25¢ per hour on carpenter work; the digging of the basement .20¢ per hour. I also interviewed Mr. Leggatt at Swan River. He will be ready to paint as soon as the school of completed and I will arrange to take him up. His charge will be .50¢ per hour and he also will employ Indian help.

The following additional will have to be purchased, and I would request authority to buy same:

1-roll of hay wire (for holding forms)
4-3½" paint brushes (for Indian use painting)
1-slush scraper (approximately $12.00)

I would also like to take out the window next to the chimney as this is liable to make cross lighting, and substitute two small ventilating windows high up in the classroom. There would be no additional cost for the small windows, the lumber firm would agree to make a trade. The only cost would be - 2 pairs of 2"

August 3, 1940.

I beg to advise that I returned from a visit to the Shoal River School, yesterday and have to report as follows.

The carpenter work at the school will not be completed until the 20th. of the month, and the painter will be ready to move in at that time. Work sheets are enclosed herewith in an amount of $617.10, and the balance left in Mr. Poulsen's hands was $153.00. The difference is made up by labour sheets incompleted, as there would not be sufficient money to continue paying the Indians for their work and also pay Mr. Poulsen's wages. A further $500.00 is required. This is made up as follows:

- Mr. Poulsen, wages: $300.00
- Painting, estimated: $150.00
- Clearing grounds etc.: $50.00

$500.00

There will also be a few outstanding accounts, pails, posts and additional nails amounting to approximately $9.00. I also had to purchase hinges for cupboards, screen buttons and screws, approximate cost $2.18.

There was only sufficient grey paint for the outside of the building, no trim. There is no paint for the inside and I am informed that the "Donnacona" board should be painted as soon as it is put on the wall. The following quantities of paint are required if the building is to be completed.

- 8-gals. flat wall paint (inside painting) white.
- 2- " white paint for outside trim.
- 3- " shingle stain (black)
- 10- lbs powdered glue (sizing for walls)
- 1- gal. oil.
Addition shingle stain is asked for as the painter considers there is not enough on hand to cover roofs of building and porches.

The materials and accountable cheque should reach me as soon as possible as I intend to again visit the reserve on the 20th of the month.

The materials, if purchased from Ottawa, should be addressed as follows:

Mr. Wm. Poulsen,
C/O Mr. Isaac Bradburry,
Mafeking, Manitoba.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 3rd instant arrangements will be made to forward you an additional cheque for $500.00 in connection with the Shoal River School.

AIR MAIL

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 26th instant in which you intimate that the Shoal River Indian Day School has been constructed and that a man is now engaged in the painting of the building.

I note also that the Monarch Lumber Company have delivered the materials necessary for the construction of a teacher's residence at the Waterhen Reserve.

I regret to state that it will not be possible to accept your suggestion and have Mr. Poulsen superintend the construction of this building. The files here indicate that authority was granted by the Minister's office on July 9 to employ Paul Dufault of Skownan, Man., as carpenter-foreman on this job.

It is highly desirable that this work should be undertaken and completed at an early date. A cheque for $700.00 to cover the cost of labour will reach you in the course of a few days.

Yours truly,

Sir,

Re: 126-11-5

I beg to advise that the painter completed the job of painting the school and out-houses on the 5th instant. The building is now ready for the furnace, and I beg to suggest that a pipeless furnace be installed. The roof should also be fitted with eaves-troughs otherwise the basement will be wet after every rain. This work could be done at the time the furnace is installed. It was found that a piece of blackboard was missing. The matter has been taken up with Mr. Glen Burrell and he has arranged the purchase of a new piece from the Monarch Lumber Co. Limited and arrangements have been made to have the piece fitted as soon as it is delivered to the reserve.

The enclosed snaps, taken before the building was painted, will give some idea of the construction. I wish to say that I consider all work well done. Both the carpenter and painter were high class workmen, reliable and honest and there was no hitch in the work from start to finish. Both men got along very well with the Indians.

Sir,

Re: 126-11-5.

With reference to Department letter of the 12th instant, I beg to advise that I sought the advice of the Gurney Company in regard to the size of a furnace of sufficient capacity for the heating of the Shoal River Day School. The information and cut is enclosed herewith.

A furnace, pipeless, with a heating capacity rating of 25,000 cubic feet would be ample for a building the size of the new Shoal River Day School. In asking for a pipeless furnace for this school, I have in mind the long distance from a tinsmith. A furnace with pipe heat conductors is dangerous as there is always a possibility of the children knocking them down in the course of play, and repair work would be expensive at a point so far from civilization.

The fire-box of the furnace shown is of ample size, 40 X 19 inches, a wood burner being required. The Gurney Company asked permission to quote a price and this price f.o.b. Mafeking, the nearest railway point to the reserve, is $235.85.

Mr. Poulsen informed me that there is a first class furnace man in Swan River who would be quite capable of installing the furnace. I would also be pleased to receive advice in regard to the installation of eavestroughing as this is very necessary if the cement basement is to be protected. The tinsmith could erect the eavestroughing at the time the furnace is installed.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

March 20, 1942.

Sir,

Re: 126-11-5

I beg to advise that the doors of the new school at the Shoal River Reserve are too closely fitted and have jammed during the winter. Great difficulty has been experienced in opening the doors and there is nobody on the reserve or in the district that is capable of doing the work of refitting.

I beg to suggest that at treaty payments on this reserve I be authorized to take a carpenter up with me so that this work may be done during the payment. The cost of sending a carpenter in would be very expensive as there would be car and boat charges. The cost, if the carpenter came in with the treaty party, would be the cost of actual labour. I would also suggest that Mr. Poulson, who built the school, be allowed to do the work.

The cement floor in the basement is affected with acid in the soils and sooner or later the floor will have to be refinished with cement. I would like Mr. Poulson's advice in regard to this matter.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Shoal River Indian Day School.

Dear Sir:

Receipt is acknowledged of your letter of January 31 enclosing the report of your inspection of the Shoal River Indian Day School and your expense account in this connection, which has been approved for payment.

The deficiencies of equipment and the need for certain repairs will be taken up with our local officials.

It is gratifying to receive your assurance that there is a good spirit in the school and that the children are making progress in their school work. Mrs. Hicks will be requested to increase her attention to the supervision of recreational activities.

The improvement of Mrs. Hicks' professional techniques presents a more difficult problem. I note that you have shown her as possessing six years' teaching experience and a permanent special permit for Manitoba. On her application for the position to which she was appointed on April 1, 1947, she claimed no actual teaching experience before that date and only an incomplete course of about three years at Kelvin Technical High School, Winnipeg. Doubtless she has received some advice on methods of teaching from her husband, but
she should, as you suggest, attend a summer course in Pedagogy if she is eligible for admission.

The present enrolment of thirty-six is three fewer than in September. Some children of the Roman Catholic faith from this reserve are attending the residential school at Pine Creek. As you make no mention of lack of accommodation for non-treaty children whose attendance it is desired to arrange, I infer that this problem has been satisfactorily solved.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Henry,
Superintendent of Education.
February 11, 1949.

Mr. W. Cowans,

Sheal River Indian Day School.

We have now received Mr. Rhind's inspection report on the above school and you will find attached copy of a letter to him concerning Mrs. Hicks' professional techniques.

He comments on the lack of library books at this school and I would ask that you ensure that we receive a library requisition from this school, in accordance with the February 1949 issue of the Bulletin.

Mr. Rhind also comments on the pupils' use of an open pail and having only three cups for drinking purposes.

You are therefore authorized to purchase for this school a small covered drinking receptacle such as can be purchased from Meyers or Christie School Supply catalogue. (If you have not already a catalogue from these school supply companies on hand, I would suggest that you write for them.) Their addresses are as follows:

Christie School Supply Company, P.O. Box 300, Brandon, Man.

Meyer School Supplies, Limited, Winnipeg, Manitoba.

You can also make local purchase of three dozen aluminum or plastic cups for use by these children.
He also comments on the need for interior decoration in this school. I would suggest that you prepare a requisition for the number of gallons of Kem-Tone or similar interior wall paint so that this work can be carried out either during the Easter or summer holidays by local Indian or other labour. We recommend that the room walls below blackboard level be painted field green and that a very pale green be used on the walls above blackboard level.

The use of Kem-Tone of course is only recommended where the walls are of wallboard or plaster.

Mr. Rhind also comments on the need for repairs in the basement and the fact that no flag was flying. It is presumed that we will hear from you in this regard.

You might also interview Mrs. Hicks as to the possibility of having her attend a short Summer School this year. Mr. Rhind advises that this is necessary if she is to bring these children along in accordance with the course of study.

With further reference to your letter File 543-1-5(E) dated February 11th 1949 I wish to advise you of the following:

A. Mrs. Hicks has been requested to forward requisition for library books as mentioned.

B. Drinking receptacle has been supplied and forwarded.

C. Plastic cups ordered but hard to get.

D. All paint required for the redecorating of this school has been shipped.

E. With regards repairs to the basement of this school, I would advise that the school be moved to the west, or east, some 40 feet and put on a cement foundation without any basement this I believe is the only way in which we can get away from the high water level, which causes the basement to flood.

It would be possible to have the school moved to the other side of the reserve across the river, this of course would be a hardship on both the children and the teacher as they would have to supply a boat for this purpose, or have a bridge build for them.

Then of course it would be a costly job to have the school moved to the other side of the river, there would be little or no shelter, I therefore feel that the school should not be moved but rather the action taken as mentioned above in (E).

F. The question of Mrs. Hicks taking a short summer course was taken up with her on my last visit to that reserve, Mrs.
Colonel Neary:

1. Trout River Day School:
   - Basement: For several years this basement has been the cause of complaints of expense for "bailing," "repair," etc. High water seems to recur during the first half of May.

   This school was built in 1941, about 100 yards from the church-owned teacherage which seems to be trouble-free.

   Mr. Howans is experiencing his first spring in the district. Perhaps he should take another longer look when flood conditions recur and determine whether the basement can be drained or sealed. He has convinced himself that the best solution is to move the building off the basement, but that move will entail a different installation for heating.

2. Teacher Training: It might be significant to discover what Mrs. Hicks' plans for this summer and next year are. Is there to be a time limit on the tenure of uncertificated teachers who neglect the opportunities that summer sessions afford?

Dear Sir:

In reply to your favour requesting information re Split Lake, Nelson River and Churchill Indians, I have to state that the Split Lake Indians number about 250 and get their living by hunting and fishing during the winter and working in the H. B. Coy's freighting boats during the summer.

Roughly speaking their hunting grounds extend from the N. West to Waskowaga Lake then on to the junction of Little & Ot. O. Rivers, east to Limestone & Fox Rivers then in a line towards wintering lake. The Churchill River Indians number about 400 and get their living same as the Split Lake Band. I cannot define their hunting grounds but would be safe in estimating that they hunt about 60 miles in every direction from Nelson House, which would give you a circle about 120 miles in diameter with N. House as the centre.

Having heard that the Department to Nelson River to provide a school and a grant towards paying a teacher I beg to make application for the same favour to be extended to Split Lake in case the Indians do not get treaty this year.

I would undertake to teach the school and there is a building which with a small utility could easily be used as a temporary school house. We would also need a grant of books, slates, pencils, ink and lesson charts.

(Sd.) Chas. F. Pax, Anglican Missionary.

P. S. We have had Indian school teaching the children in their own language since December and we have an average 20 and I am quite sure we would have this average all the year. In summer we would have about 60 on the roll.

(Sd.) C.G.F.
Winnipeg, 26th March, 1907.

Sir,

Nevertheless, a matter is brought up which might be attended to without delay, viz., the giving of a grant toward the maintenance of a school at Split Lake. If the Department takes a favourable view of this suggestion, which I hope it will, I would like to be informed soon, in order that supplies such as school books, other school material and also a small supply of medicines, may be ordered in time to be shipped by the earliest opportunity.

Your obedient servant,

Sgd. D. Laird,
