Sir,—The School situation at Split Lake requires attention at the earliest convenience of the Department. I found that school was being kept in a room of the Missionary's house and the Rev Mr Fox was conducting but was much hampered in his work by lack of proper accommodation.

I had hoped to have a conversation with the Rev gentleman when I made the last summer payments but he was in Ontario on holiday and I was unable to see him.

I regard him as the man who can be trusted to superintend the erection of the much needed building for School purposes.

I have hesitated to make any special recommendation in the case of Split Lake because there are very few houses built in the vicinity of the Fort and Mission and the number of children who could attend in winter would be very few indeed. During the summer the Indians tent on the Hudson's Bay Company's grounds largely and children might attend then but the Missionary takes holidays at that season of the year. So that the early Fall seems to be about the only time when a full attendance might be expected.

Another feature of the case is presented by the fact that the Reserve has not yet been surveyed and the Indians are uncertain as to what the limits of their Reserve may be. They are hesitating to build until they know where they are safe in building. When this matter is settled but until then it would be difficult to locate the School.

No special pressure was brought to bear upon me on this subject of School building during the last summer. They mentioned the matter merely and said they expected the Government to keep faith with them on the question but they were in no way impatient.
In a matter like this I do not think that we should wait for the people to clamor for educational privileges. We should lead them rather than wait until they crowd us. I therefore recommend that steps be taken to erect a suitable school building forthwith. I would further urge the survey of the Reserve so as to determine the most suitable site. I am averse to placing the School on Mission Property. It must as the Department knows be near to the majority of the people.

The building when erected must of necessity be a log structure roofed with boards and covered with mica roofing. Freighting to Split Lake is expensive and must therefore be reduced to a minimum. Lumber must be cut on the ground and by hand. This can be done so that only windows nails and roofing material need to be purchased and freighted in.

In my best judgement the cost of a building at this point will be about $600.00 and I recommend that the contract be given to the Rev Mr Fox who is reliable and capable.

I have the honor to be

Your Obedient Servant

John Summers
Inspector of Indian Agencies

Dear Sir,

The Indians in Council assembled have asked me to approach the Department through you and beg that something more be done for them from an educational point of view.

In discussing the matter they pointed out the splendid buildings erected at Norway House, Cross Lake and The Pas, I have, at their request, asked the Department several times for a boarding school, but have been informed that there were no funds for this purpose.

Might I suggest an improved day school and earnestly beg the Department to consider this. It would be an uplifting and very encouraging institution for the Indians, while not breaking up the home life and unfitting the children for life as Indians. We have 185 children of school age, about 100 boys and 85 girls. I can assure you Mr. Bunn the 95% of those would attend an improved day school in the summer, and if the Department saw their way to keep the school open during the winter, 50% could easily be induced to attend during the winter, as the men would leave their families on the Reserve while they went hunting. Then one good warm meal would mean so much to the young Indians who often have to go for days without a good meal.

I have tried a day school but it was not a success. Then I have always impressed the parents with the fact that they must teach their
Children to read and write in their own language, this has been done to a certain extent, and most of our Indians can read and write in their own language.

Education must be a preparation for success in life, and an improved school would be this, under the conditions at Split Lake. The H. B. Ry. will be within 25 miles of Split Lake next summer so that material for school could easily be taken over land in winter and suitable building erected.

Before the railway came, it would have been a very great expense to the Department, and I can understand the Department hesitating before incurring the expense.

However the reserve is now surveyed, and a school site allotted. Then there is a large plot of land given to the church part of which might be used for school site and farming operations so that the site would present no difficulty whatever.

Realizing your kindness and immortality in dealing with everything connected with the welfare of the Indians. I hope you will see your way to consider this request and if possible present our needs to the Department for consideration.

Yours sincerely,

(Sgd.) C. G. Fox

Mr. Scott,

With reference to the application from the Bishop of Keewatin for the establishment of an improved day school at Split Lake I beg to say that a day school was in operation there for three years from November, 1907, until the end of the December quarter, 1910, when the then teacher, the Rev. Mr. Fox, resigned. The school was not a success owing to the very low average attendance.

In the letter referred to by the Bishop from the Rev. Mr. Fox, which was sent to the Department in April, 1916, Mr. Fox suggested the establishment of an improved day school and pointed out that there were about one hundred children of school age there, the large majority of whom could attend during the summer. This letter was forwarded to the Department by Mr. Bunn, but no action was taken.

The next we hear of this school was in a communication from Mr. Fletcher, the Deputy Minister of Education for the province of Manitoba, who wrote on the 30th of January, 1917, that he was informed that there are a number of children of school age at Split Lake and also some white and half-breed children, for whose education they would be responsible. He wanted to know whether it would be feasible for this Department to co-operate with his Department in the establishment of a school there and, if so, on what terms.

Several letters have passed between this Department and the Deputy Minister of Education for Manitoba and in a letter just received from Mr. Fletcher he quotes from a communication received from Mr. J. A. Campbell, M.P., at present Commissioner for Northern Manitoba, who had been making inquiries concerning the situation at Split Lake. Mr. Campbell states that there are very few, if any, half-breed children there, probably four or five at the most, but that there is a large number of Indian children, about seventy. He also states that the English Church and the Dominion...
Dominion authorities have now taken steps to establish a school there.

The Department was advised that there was a building formerly used as the Northwest Mounted Police Barracks at Split Lake which might be available for school purposes and application was made to the Comptroller of the Royal Northwest Mounted Police to find out whether the building referred to could be obtained for this purpose and, if so, on what terms. The Department was advised by the Mounted Police Department that the Minister had authorized the use of the building, rent free; provided it is kept in good repair and the necessary alterations made at the expense of this Department. This offer was confirmed by Order in Council dated the 4th of May, 1917.

The Bishop states that the Rev. Mr. Walter has, on his own account, begun a day school at the mission and carried it on during the past summer and that he is using the church, which is the only available building and that he has no proper school material.

We have had no returns showing the attendance, but, if there are enough pupils to warrant carrying on a school at this point, the Department would be justified in making use of the police barracks and furnishing the necessary school material and providing a salary for the teacher. When the school was previously in operation $200.00 was all that was allowed.

Mr. Agent Macdonald wrote the Department on the 1st of August, last, stating that while he was at Split Lake the Indians requested the Department to furnish them with a school and they guaranteed that from thirty to forty children would take advantage of it. The Agent reports that he looked over the Mounted Police Barracks and that very few alterations would be needed and that he was given to understand by the Manager of the Hudson's Bay Company that the stoves and furniture in the barracks could be purchased very reasonably from the Mounted Police. He has also reported that his return the Rev. Mr. Walters has been appointed to Split Lake, who would be available as a teacher.

In reply to his letter he was told that this Department is in communication with the Deputy Minister of Education.
Education for Manitoba, who had been asked to make the necessary arrangements for securing a suitable teacher and the opening of the school, this Department to pay two-thirds of the expenses.

A requisition for supplies from Mr. Walter was forwarded by Mr. Macdonald and this requisition and a copy of Mr. Macdonald's letter were forwarded to Mr. Fletcher and the Agent was so informed.

From a letter just received from Mr. Fletcher it appears that his Department is not particularly anxious to take any action in regard to a school at this point and it rests with this Department to arrange for its maintenance.

I would suggest that Mr. Fletcher be asked to return the requisition which was sent him, so that it can be filled here. Before incurring any expense for alterations to the Mounted Police Barracks and for equipment it might be well to wait for a return showing the attendance. In any event the work could hardly be done this winter.

Sir,

Your letter dated Nov 25 1918 sent to the Bishop of Kawatia re Indian School has been sent on to me, and I hasten to send information asked.

The number of names in the register is 51. There are boys and girls between the ages of 6 and 16. Girls 30. Boys 21.

The school was opened 12 times and then the most of the children left for the hunting grounds with their parents, and we thought it unwise to heat the Church for the sake of about 20 children. The accompanying two photos were taken after some hard life. One or two of the older girls could repeat the
Alphabet and one could read a word or two in English when I started. Before they left they could nearly all repeat the alphabet, some of them knew their twice times table and most could do the simplest addition and subtraction. All this was of course in English. But I have no teaching plant except & reading cards, large size, and a few books on arithmetic far too advanced for them. Mr MacDonald the Indian Agent at The Pas is acquainted with the conditions here, and I have been in communication with him. I am willing to teach 15 hours a week until you can get a teacher. At a band meeting held on the Split Lake Reserve on the 5th day of July 1919, the band brought up the question of a school on the reserve. There are 165 children on the reserve, about half of that number being of school age. There is an old Mounted Police Barracks on the reserve which is vacant at the present time, and in the meantime, if it could be secured, would answer for a school.

The barracks is 24x24 with a nine foot ceiling downstairs, and is worth in its present condition about $200.00. It is built of logs and has an upstairs and two good floors. It is divided downstairs into four rooms by board partitions. It has four windows, one of them only a half a one. There would be required two large windows in addition to the ones in, and a small porch over the front door. The partition lumber will make this porch. It requires some plaster on the outside and enough lime to whitewash the inside, and will cost not over $100.00 to make it ready for the seats. This building when repaired should be good for five years, and seats for say 40 pupils and a blackboard 3 x 12 will have to be furnished.

Bishop Lofthouse was on the reserve at the time of my visit, and he agreed to Mr Walton, the resident Clergyman, teaching for half a day for five days in the week when the children are at home. This arrangement appears to be the best one possible at the present time, and I would recommend that the Department should arrange to take over and use this building.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir,

I have just returned from visiting an Indian mission in the North, and spent some time at Opitik Lake.

At this mission there is very great need of a good day school, and our missionary, Rev. W. H. J. Walter, is prepared to do all in his power to assist; but there is no school building, school being held at present in the church.

The Indians are willing to get out logs for a school building and also to do a great part of construction, if the Dep't would assist them in the matter of food during the time they are at work. It would also be necessary for them to have doors, windows and furniture found on site can be used on the mission property which would be most convenient.

I should be deeply grateful if anything could be done in this matter for the need is great.

Sir,

I have the honor to state that the Indians at Split Lake have asked that a day school be opened at that point. They ask that it be carried on for only four months of the year, in the summer.

The missionary Mr. Walters states that he is willing to teach a school such as the above, but only for half a day for four or five days a week providing that the Department supplies desks and purchases a building for a school.

This would work out as follows. The children would be taught for about eighty half days in the summer and have holidays for eight months while away north with their parents on the hunt.

The building referred to is the old R.N.W.M.P. barracks and if the Department desires to go ahead with this school no doubt the R.N.W.M.P. would be agreeable to sell the property as they do not use it.

I do not feel like recommending that the school be opened on these terms, as I know that all the children would learn in such a short term would be wasted and forgotten before the next year.

The missionary at present carries on a small class of pupils but receives no compensation for the work, except from the church.

Dear Sir:

Re No. 128-12-1.

Your letter of the 21st inst. addressed to Bishop Dewdney has on account of the Bishop's absence in the north been handed to me.

In reference to Missionary services at Split Lake, I beg to state that for 25 years we have carried on definite work, with a missionary resident at Split Lake. We have there a church building and a mission house, in full use.

The Rev. W. H. J. Walter, the missionary in charge of Split Lake now conducts day school, and he will, so far as we know, continue to do so. Mr. Walter is doing splendid work at Split Lake, and he, as well as ourselves, would be much gratified if a suitable school could be built.

Re correspondence No. 128-12-1 and reply on my behalf by my Commissary, Canon Lofthouse, I beg to say that I have looked carefully into the question of school provision and accommodation at Split Lake Mission, having spent a week there during the month of September. My dear Mr. Ferrier,

I beg to inform you that Rev. W.H.J.Walter, Split Lake Mission is being appointed to succeed Rev. J.F.J.Marshall who is leaving Jack River Mission this spring to take up the duties of Principal at the new Indian Residential School at Sioux Lookout.

Mr. A.D.Dawdney, who spent last summer at Pikwitonei, on the H.B.Railway, and carried on voluntarily a day school for the Indian children there with an enrolment of 19 scholars, is taking Mr.Walter's place. He will be prepared to conduct full-time school for the children at Split Lake. He will have one more year to put in College before he is ready for ordination, but as summer is the time that the Indians are on their reserve and most are away during the winter, he will be there for the period when the best work can be done.

I am hoping that the new school for which application has been made and advised by Agent Waddy will be proceeded with as the present building is in bad shape and was never intended for school purposes.

May I also say that I am appointing Mr.Herbert Cannon who taught school at York Factory the past two years to have charge of our work at Pikwitonei. I would urge that his work as teacher of Indian children be duly recognized by the Dept., as a very necessary provision for children who would otherwise be neglected. I anticipate that work on the H.B.Railway will bring more of the Indians than usual from Split Lake to the line. The enrolment last summer at Pikwitonei was 19 and the average attendance was 12.

I shall be glad to hear from you at your convenience in respect to these matters.

Most faithfully yours,

A.D. Keewatin

I wish to submit the following inspection report of the Day School at Split Lake, The Pas Agency.

Mr. Cowley is the teacher in charge. He is also the Church of England clergyman.

The school is a frame building and is badly in need of paint, both inside and out. The toilets need to be moved and repaired. Mr. Lovell left instructions that this work be carried out at once.

The roll calls for about 24 pupils. At times the attendance is good but when the Indians are away, which is the greater part of the time, the attendance drops to from 6 to 10. Mr. Cowley stated that if the Department approved he would close school next April and May and teach in July and August when the Indians are all home. I would recommend that Mr. Lovell be notified that this change is approved.

The exercise books showed very nice writing and neat work. The pupils, however, are so irregular in attendance that progress is slow and the children rarely pass grade two or three.

The day school seems to offer little hope for the solution of the education problem because to live these people must be out on the trapline.

A number of children from this reserve now attend Elkhorn Residential School. However, I feel these children could best be educated nearer home and not taken too far from their home environment. The question of education for these northern
Indians is one that deserves careful study.

There are about 85 children of school age on this reserve and their education is our responsibility. It is a problem that the department must face and indeed must solve; and the boarding school appears the only reasonable solution.

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF F. YULE, M.D.,
Medical Superintendent, The Pas Agency, dated March 1, 1946.

At Split Lake we have a good school and good desks with 26 pupils enrolled. There is no overcrowding. If this were the whole story it would be grand, but unfortunately it is not. I have it on good authority that there are approximately 84 children of school age in this Band. There are about 10 going to Elkhorn School, so we have about 36 getting some education. The children not in school are living at scattered points with their parents and in most cases, if not in all, there are too few at any of these points to form a school nucleus. Now I am only interested in getting these children educated (whether Day or Boarding School is immaterial) and I cannot see how this is to be done unless there is a central boarding-school. In this case it should be Split Lake. It is twenty-five miles from the main steel, but it would be a comparatively simple matter to make a tractor winter road and bring in a year's supplies.

Extract from Regional Supervisor Davis' report dated January 4th on the Split Lake Indian Day School.

I only visited the school for a short time, as I was busy visiting the Indians, finding out how many hours a day the school was in operation, and receiving complaints which were numerous. Most of the Indians said it was useless to send their children to school as it only started in the morning around eleven o'clock and closed at twelve; opening again around two or half-past and closing at three o'clock. No effort was made by the Rev. Cowley to teach the children.

When I visited the school there were 12 children in the classroom and an additional 40 were around the homes, who were not attending school. Mr. Grafton advised me that Rev. Cowley claimed that he taught the children in Cree; however, as Mr. Grafton can speak the language and has taught Indian children, it was quite evident that the children were not taught Cree, English or anything else. I would recommend that this man's services be dispensed with and a first class teacher engaged.

As we have not a residence at this point, arrangements should be made to have material sent in before Spring, so we can erect a residence next summer. In the meantime, a teacher could board with the Hudson's Bay Company Post Manager. There is no doubt, that Rev. Cowley has done good Missionary work but the only interest he has had in the school is the salary attached to it.

Dear Mr. Pook:

There is a vacancy for a teacher at Split Lake in Northern Manitoba near Ilford, where the Indian Superintendent is Mr. J.H. Staunton.

This area is in the Anglican Diocese of Keewatin, and the Indians of the reserve are practically all adherents of the Church of England. Until the end of June the school was conducted by the resident Missionary, Canon G.C. Cowley, who is now giving all his time to Church work.

It is desirable that the first lay teacher should be a person who is likely to co-operate fully with community leaders. A teacher trained in Manitoba is more likely to have an appreciation of the area and would find it more convenient and cheaper to reach.

Dear Sir:

I wish to acknowledge the receipt of and to thank you for your letter of October 29th. In it I note the upward revision of salary to $204.00. Had I known this prior to writing you I would not have raised the question of transportation. At the present rate of salary I am quite content to finance my transportation into Split Lake.

On Nov. 10th I went to Winnipeg and called on Mr. Rayson in this connection, and as transportation into Split Lake from Ilford at the present time would be very difficult I asked that in view of this condition and the shortness of the remainder of the full school term I be granted leave...
to remain here until the opening of the new term in January 1950. My oldest son is still in Rivette Sanatorium, T.B. condition due to Hong Kong imprisonment. He is possibly due for further surgery this month or next. By the end of December I should have more definite knowledge as to his prospects of ultimate recovery.

If this my request for extended leave is approved by you, I undertake to be in Split Lake on due date for the opening of the January school term.

Thanking you again for your continued kindness in these matters,

Remain

Yours faithfully,

George E. Jeffery

P.S.

Dear Mr. Jeffery:

I have for answer your letter of November 29 and I find that our Treasury did not forward your Retirement Fund cheque to you. There is an amount of $310.60 to your credit in this fund. As requested in your letter, it will be held until such time as you permanently leave our service.

As you are aware, we can make no guarantee as to the retention of your services at the Split Lake School after June 30, 1950. Our regulations do not permit the hiring of over-aged teachers when qualified and younger teachers are available. I have already had an application from a qualified male teacher for the Split Lake School next September.

Therefore, while your services are required up to June 30, 1950, I regret that I can make no commitment for the retention of your services after that date.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard P. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.
